editionStmt.edition: This early release includes some 500 EEBO-TCP transcriptions of Early Modern plays that have undergone several routines to create an interoperable and algorithmically amenable corpus of Early Modern Drama. Many incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words have been corrected, including obvious printers' errors, but the text has not been proofread word by word. Each word in the text has been identified as a distinct token with its own xml:id and assigned to a lemma, a part of speech, and a standard spelling. Speech prefixes were mapped to unique speaker ID's as "who" attributes of sp elements. elements

respStmt.name: Philip R. Burns

respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

div.p: The new inn or, the light heart.
A comedy. As it was never acted, but most negligently played, by some, the King's servants. And more squeamishly beheld, and censured by others, the King's subjects. 1629.
Now, at last, set at liberty to the readers, his maties servants, and subjects, to be judged. 1631.

By the author, B. Jonson.
Hor. .... me lectori credere mallem:
Quam spectatoris fastidia far superbi.
London, ¶ Printed by Thomas harper, for Thomas Alchorne, and are to be sold at his shop in Paul's churchyard, at the sign of the green dragon. Mdcxxxi.

div.head: The dedication, to the reader.
div.p:
If thou be such, I make thee my patron, and dedicate the piece to thee: if not so much, would I had been at the charge of thy better literature. Howsoever, if thou canst but spell, and join my sense; there is more hope of thee, then of a hundred fastidious impertinents,
who were there present the first day, yet never made piece of their prospect the right way. What did they come for, then? thou wil't ask me. I will as punctually answer: to see, and to be seen. To make a general muster of themselves in their clothes of credit: and possess the stage, against the play. To dislike all, but mark nothing. And by their confidence of rising between the acts, in oblique lines, make affidavit to the whole house, of their not understanding one scene. Armed, with this prejudice, as the stage-furniture, or arras-cloths, they were there, as spectators,
away. For the faces in the hangings, and they beheld alike. So I wish, they may do ever. And do trust myself, and my book, rather to thy rustic candour, than all the pomp of their pride, and solemn ignorance, to boot. Fare thee well, and fall too. read

div.head: The argument.
div.p:
The lord Frampul, a noble gentleman, well educated, and bred a scholar, in Oxford, was married young, to a virtuous gentlewoman, Sylly's daughter of the South, whose worth (Though he truly enjoyed) he never could rightly value; but, as many green husbands (Given over to their extravagant delights, and some peccant humours of their own) occasioned in his over loving wife, so deep a melancholy, by his leaving her in the time of her lying in, of her second daughter, she having
brought him only two daughters, Frances, and Laetitia: and (Out of her hurt fancy) interpreting that to be a cause of her husband's coldness in affection, her not being blessed with a son, took a resolution with herself, after her month's time, and thanksgiving rightly in the church, to quit her home, with a vow never to return, till by reducing her lord, she could bring a wished happiness to the family.

He, in the mean time returning, and hearing of this departure of his lady, began, though overlate, to resent the injury he had done her: and out of his cockbrained resolution, entered into as solemn a quest of her. Since when, neither of them had been heard of. But the eldest daughter Frances, by the title of lady Frampul, enjoyed the state, her sister being lost young, and is the sole relict of the family.

div.head: Act 1. Here begins our comedy.
div.p:
This lady, being a brave, bountiful lady, and enjoying this free, and plentiful estate, hath an ambitious disposition to be esteemed the mistress of many servants, but loves none. And hearing of a famous new-inn, that is kept by a merry host, called good-stock, in Barnet, invites some lords, and gentlemen to wait on her thither, as well to see the fashions of the place, as to make themselves merry, with the accidents on the by. It happens, there is a melancholic gentleman, one master Lovel, hath been lodged there some days before in the inn, who (Unwilling to be seen) is surprised by the lady, and invited by prudence, the lady's chambermaid, who is
elected governess of the sports, in the inn, for that day, and installed their sovereign Lovel is persuaded by the host, and yields to the lady's invitation, which concludes the first act. having revealed his quality before, to the host.

div.head: In the second act.
div.p:
Prudence, and her lady express their anger conceived, at the tailor, who had promised to make prudence a new suit, and bring it home, as on the eve, against this day. But, he failing of his word, the lady had commanded a standard of her own best apparel to be brought down: and prudence is so fitted. The lady being put in mind, that she is there alone without other company of women, borrows (By the advice of Pru) the hosts son of the house, whom they
dress with the hosts consent, like a lady, and send out the coachman, with the empty coach, as for a kinswoman of her ladyships, mistress Laetitia silly, to bear her company: who attended with his nurse, an old charwoman in the inn, dressed oddly by the hosts council, is believed to be a lady of quality, and so received, entertained, and love made to her, by the young lord Beaufort, etc.: in the mean time, the fly of the inn is discovered to colonel glorious, with the militia of the house, below the stairs, in the drawer, tapster, chamberlain, and ostler, inferior officers, with the coachman Trundle, ferret, etc. And, the preparation is made, to the lady's design upon Lovel, his upon her, and the sovereigns upon both.

div.head: Here begins, at the third act, the epitasis, or business of the play.
div.p:
Lovel, by the dexterity, and wit of the sovereign of the sports, prudence; having two hours assigned him, of free colloquy, and love-making to his mistress, one, after dinner, the other after supper; the court being set, is demanded by the lady Frampul, what love is? as doubting if there were any such power, or no. To whom, he first by definition, and after by argument answers, proving, and describing the effects. of love, so vively, as she, who had derided the name of love before, hearing his discourse, is now so taken both with the man, and his matter, as she confesseth herself enamoured of him, and, but for the ambition she hath to enjoy the other hour, had presently
declared herself: which gives both him, and the spectator's occasion to think she yet dissembles, notwithstanding the payment of her kiss, which he celebrates. And the court dissolves, upon a news brought, of a new lady, a newer coach, and a new coachman called Barnaby.

div.head: Act 4.
div.p:
The house being put into a noise, with the rumor of this new lady, and there being drinking below in the court, the colonel, sir glorious, with bat: Burst, a broken citizen, and Hodge Huffle his champion; she falls into their hands, and being attended but with one footman, is uncivilly entreated by them, and a quarrel commenced, but is rescued by the valour of Lovel; which beheld by the lady Frampul, from the window, she is
invited up, for safety, where coming, and conducted by the host, her gown is first discovered to be the same with the whole suit, which was bespoken for Pru: and she herself, upon examination, found to be Pinnacia Stuffe, the tailor's wife, who was wont to be preoccupied in all his customers best clothes, by the footman her husband. They are both condemned, and censured, she stripped like a doxy, and sent home a foot. In the interim, the second hour goes on, and the question, at suit of the lady Frampul, is changed from love to valour; which ended, he receives his second kiss, and by the rigor of the sovereign, falls into a fit of melancholy, worse, or more desperate than the first.

The fifth, and last act is the catastrophe, or knitting up of all, where fly
brings word to the host, of the lord Beaufort's being married privately in the new stable, to the supposed lady, his son; which the host receives as an omen of mirth. But complains, that Lovel is gone to bed melancholic, when prudence appears dressed in the new suit applauded by her lady, and employed to retrieve Lovel. The host encounters them, with this relation of l. Beaufort's marriage, which is seconded by the l. Latimer, and all the servants of the house. In this while, l. Beaufort comes in, and professes it, calls for his bed, and bride-bowl, to be made ready, the host forbids both, shows whom he hath married, and discovers him to be his son, a boy. The lord bridegroom confounded, the nurse enters like a frantic bed lem, cries out on fly, says she is undone, in her daughter, who is confessed to
be the lord Frampul's child, sister to the other lady, the host to be their father. She his wife. He finding his children, bestows them one on Lovel, the other on the lord Beaufort, the inn upon fly, who had been a Gipsy with him, offers a portion with prudence, for her wit, which is refused; and she taken, by the lord Latimer, to wife; for the crown of her virtue, and goodness. And all are contented.

div.head: The scene Barnet. The persons of the play. With some short characterism of the chief actors.
div.p: Good-stock, the host (Played well) alias, the lord Frampul. He pretends to be a gentleman, and a scholar, neglected by the times, turns host, and keeps an inn, the sign of the light heart, in Barnet: is supposed to have one only son, but is found to have none, but two daughters, Francis, and Laetitia, who was lost young. Etc.

Lovel. A complete gentleman, a soldier, and a scholar, is a melancholy guest in the inn. first quarrelled, after, much honoured, and beloved by the host. He is known to have been page, to the old lo. Beaufort, followed him in the French wars, after a companion of his studies, and left guardian to his son. He is assisted in his love to the lady Frampul, by the host, and the chambermaid, prudence. He was one, that acted well too.
Ferret. Who is also called Stote, and vermin, is lovels servant, a fellow of a quick, nimble wit, knows the manners and affections of people, and can make profitable, and timely discoveries of them.

Frank. Supposed a boy, and the hosts son, borrowed to be dressed for a lady, and set up as a stale by prudence, to catch Beaufort, or Latimer, proves to be Laetitia, sister to Frances, and lord Frampul's younger daughter, stolen by a beggar-woman, shorn, put into boys apparel, sold to the host, and brought up by him as his son.

Nurse. A poor charwoman in the inn, with one eye, that tends the boy, is thought the Irish beggar that sold him, but is truly the lady Frampul; who left her home melancholic, and jealous that her lord loved her not, because she brought him none but daughters, and lives, unknown to her husband, as he to her.

Frances. Supposed the lady Frampul, being reputed his sole daughter, and heir, the barony descending upon her, is a lady of great fortunes, and beauty, but fantastical: thinks nothing a felicity, but to have a multitude of servants, and be called mistress by them, comes to the inn to
be merry, with a chambermaid only, and her servants her guests, etc.

Prudence. The chambermaid, is elected sovereign of the sports in the inn, governs all, commands, and so orders, as the lord Latimer is exceedingly taken with her, and takes her to his wife, in conclusion.

Lord Latimer and lord Beaufort, are a pair of young lords, servants and guests to the lady Frampul, but as Latimer falls enamoured of prudence, so doth Beaufort on the boy, the hosts son, set up for Laetitia, the younger sister, which she proves to be indeed.

Sir glorious Tipto. A knight, and colonel, hath the luck to think well of himself, without a rival, talks gloriously of any thing, but very seldom is in the right. He is the lady's guest, and her servant too; but this day utterly neglects his service, or that him. For he is so enamoured on the fly of the inn, and the militia below stairs, with Hodge Huffle, and bat: Burst, guests that come in, and trundle, Barnabe, etc. as no other society relisheth with him.
Fly. Is the parasite of the inn, visitor general of the house, one that had been a strolling Gipsy, but now is reclaimed, to be Inflamer of the reckonings.
Peirce. The drawer, knighted by the colonel, styled sir pierce, and young anon, one of the chief of the infantry.
Jordan. The chamberlain, another of the militia, and an officer commands the tertia of the beds.
Jug. The tapster, a thoroughfare of news.
Peck. The ostler.
Bat: Burst. A broken citizen, an in and in man.
Hodge Huffle. A cheater, his champion.
Nick Stuffe. The lady's tailor.
Pinnacia Stuffe. His wife.
Trundle. A coachman.
Barnabe. A hired coachman.
Staggers. The smith. Only talked on.
Tree. The saddler.

lg.l: You are welcome, welcome all, to the new inn;
Though the old house, we hope our cheer will win
Your acceptation: we ha' the same cook,
Still, and the fat, who says, you shall not look
Long, for your bill of fare, but every dish
Be served in, i'the time, and to your wish:
If any thing be set to a wrong taste,
'Tis not the meat, there, but the mouth's displaced,
Remove but that sick palate, all is well.
For this, the secure dresser bad me tell,
Nothing more hurts just meetings, than a crowd;
Or, when the expectation's grown too loud:
That the nice stomach, would ha' this or that,
And being asked, or urged, it knows not what:
When sharp, or sweet, have been too much a feast,
And both out lived the palate of the guest.
Beware to bring such appetites to the stage,
They do confess a weak, sick, queasy age,
And a shrewd grudging too of ignorance ,
When clothes and faces 'bove the men advance:
Hear for your health, then, but at any hand,
Before you judge, vouchsafe to understand,
Concoct, digest: if then, it do not hit,
Some are in a consumption of wit,
Deep, he dares say, he will not think, that all —
For hectics are not epidemical.

div.head: Scene 1.
div.l: I am not pleased, indeed, you are i'the right;
Nor is my house pleased, if my sign could speak,
The sign o'the light heart. There, you may read it;
So may your master too, if he look on't.
A heart weighed with a feather, and out weighed too:
A brain-child o'mine own! and I am proud on't!
And if his worship think, here, to be melancholy,
In spite of me or my wit, he is deceived;
I will maintain the rebus 'gainst all humours,
And all complexions i'the body of man,
That's my word, or i'the isle of Britain!
You have reason good mine host.

sp.speaker: Host
sp.l: Sir I have rhyme too.
Whether it be by chance or art,
A heavy purse makes a light heart.
There 'tis expressed! first, by a purse of gold,
A heavy purse, and then two turtles, makes,
A heart with a light stuck in't, a light heart!
Old abbot Islip could not invent better,
Or prior Bolton with his bolt and tun.
I am an innkeeper, and know my grounds,
And study 'em; brain o'man, I study 'em:
I must ha' jovial guests to drive my ploughs,
And-whistling boys to bring my harvest home,
Or I shall hear no flails thwack. Here, your master,
And you ha' been this fortnight, drawing fleas
Out of my mats, and pounding 'em in cages
Cut out of cards, and those roped round with packthread,
Drawn thorough birdlime! A fine subtlety!
Or poring through a multiplying glass,
Upon a captived crab-louse, or a cheese-mite
To be dissected, as the sports of nature,
With a neat Spanish needle! Speculations
That do become the age, I do confess!
As measuring an aunt's eggs, with the silkworms,
By a fantastic instrument of thread,
Shall give you their just difference, to a hair!
Or else recovering o'dead flies, with crumbs!
(Another quaint conclusion i'the physics)
Which I ha' seen you busy at, through the keyhole -
But never had the fate to see a fly —
Alive i'your cups, or once heard, drink mine host,
Or such a cheerful chirping charm come from you.

div.head: Scene 2.
div.l: What's that? what's that?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: A buzzing of mine
About a fly! A murmur that he has.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Sir I am telling your Stote here, monsieur ferret, host
For that I hear's his name) and dare tell you, sir,
If you have a mind to be melancholy, and musty,
There's footman's inn, at the town's end, the stocks,
Or carrier's place, at sign o'the broken wain,
Mansions of state! Take up your harbour there;
There are both flies and fleas, and all variety
Of vermin, for inspection, or dissection.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: We ha' set our rest up here, sir, i'your heart.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Sir set your heart at rest, you shall not do it:
Unless you can be jovial. Brain o'man,
Be jovial first, and drink, and dance, and drink.
Your lodging here, and wi' your daily dumps,
●s a mere libel gain' my house and me;
And, then, your scandalous commons.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: How mine host?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Sir, they do scandal me, upo'the road, here
A poor quotidian rack o'mutton, roasted,
●rie, to be grated! and that driven down
With bear, and buttermilk, mingled together,
Or clarified whey, instead of claret!
It is against my freehold, my inheritance,
my magna charta, cour laetificat,
To drink such balderdash , or bonny clabbee!
Gi'me good wine, or Catholic, or christian,
Wine is the word, that glads the heart of man:
And mine's the house of wine, sack, says my bush,
Be merry, and drink sherry; that's my poesy!
For I shall never joy i'my light heart,
So long as I conceive a sullen guest,
Or any thing that's earthy!

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: Humorous host.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: I care not if I be.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: But airy also,
Not to defraud you of your rights, or trench
Upo' your privileges, or great charter,
(For those are every ostler's language now)
Say, you were born beneath those smiling stars,
Have made you lord, and owner of the heart,
Of the light heart in Barnet; suffer us
Who are more Saturnine, t'enjoy the shade
Of your round roof yet.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Sir I keep no shades
Nor shelters, I: for either owls or reremice.

div.head: Scene 3.
div.l: He'll make you a bird of night, sir.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Bless you child,
You'll make yourselves such.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: 'That your son mine host?

div.stage: En. Fra. to his child o'the by the host speak●

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: He's all the sons I have sir.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: Pretty boy!
Goes he to school?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: O lord, sir, he prates Latin
●d 'twere a parrot, or a play. boy.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: Thou —
Commend'st him fitly.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: To the pitch, he flies, sir,
He'll tell you what is Latin for a lookingglass,
Beard-brush, rubber, or quick-warming pan.

sp.speaker: Lovel
sp.l: What's that?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l:
A wench, i'the inn-phrase, is all these;
A lookingglass in her eye,
A beard-brush with her lips,
A rubber with her hand,
And a warming pan with her hips.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: This, in your scurrile dialect. But my inn
●owes no such language.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.l: That's because, mine host,
You do profess the teaching him yourself.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Sir, I do teach him somewhat. By degrees,
●d with a funnel, I make shift to fill
The narrow vessel, he is but yet, a bottle.

sp.speaker: Lov
sp.l: O let him lose no time, though.

sp.speaker: Host
sp.l: Sir, he does not.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: And less his manners.

sp.speaker: Host
sp.l: I provide for those, too.
●me hither Frank, speak to the gentleman
Latin: he is melancholy; say,
●ong to see him merry, and so would treat him.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Subtristis visu' es esse aliquantulùm patri,
●ite lautè excipere, etiam a● tractare gestit.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: Pulchro.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Tell him, I fear it bodes us some ill luck,
●s too reservedness.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Veretur pa●er,
〈◊〉 quid nobis mali ominis apportet iste
●mis praeclusus vultus.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: Bellè. A fine child!
●u won't part with him, mine host?

sp.speaker: H.
sp.l: Who told you
Would not?

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: I but ask you.

sp.speaker: Host
sp.l: And I answer.
To whom? for what?

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: To me, to be my page.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: I know no mischief yet the child hath done,
to deserve such a destiny.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: Why?

sp.speaker: H●..
sp.l: Go down boy,
And get your breakfast. Trust me, I had rather
Take a fair halter, wash my hands, and hang him
Myself, make a clean riddance of him: then.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: What?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Then dam him to that desperate course of life.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: Call you that desperate, which by a line
Of institution, from our ancestors,
Hath been derived down to us, and received
In a succession, for the noblest way
Of breeding up our youth, in letters, arms,
Fair mien, discourses, civil exercise,
And all the blazon of a gentleman?
Where can he learn to vault, to ride, to fence,
To move his body gracefuller? to speak
His language purer? or to tune his mind,
Or manners, more to the harmony of nature
Then, in these nurseries of nobility? —

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: I that was, when the nursery's self, was noble
And only virtue made it, not the mercate,
That titles were not vented at the drum,
Or common outcry; goodness gave the greatness,
And greatness worship: every house became
An academy of honour, and those parts —
We see departed, in the practice, now,
Quite from the institution.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: Why do you say so?
Or think so enviously? do they not still
Learn there, the centaur's skill, the art of Thrace,
To ride? or Pollux mystery , to fence?
The pyrrhic gestures, both to dance, and spring
In armour, to be active for the wars?
To study figures, numbers, and proportions,
May yield 'em great in counsels, and the arts
Grave Nestor, and the wise Ulysses practised?
To make their English sweet upon their tongue!
As reverend Chaucer says?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Sir you mistake,
To play sir Pandarus my copy hath it,
And carry messages to madam Cressid.
Instead of backing the brave steed, o'mornings,
To mount the chambermaid; and for a leap
O'the vaulting horse, to ply the vaulting house:
For exercise of arms, a bale of dice,
Or two or three packs of cards, to show the cheat,
And nimbleness of hand: mistake a cloak
From my lords back, and pawn it. Ease his pockets
Of a superfluous watch, or geld a jewel
Of an odd stone, or so. Twinge three or four buttons
From off my lady's gown. These are the arts,
Or seven liberal deadly sciences
Of pagery, or rather paganism,
As the tides run. To which, if he apply him,
He may, perhaps, take a degree at Tyburn,
A year the earlier: come to read a lecture
Upon Aquinas at s. Thomas a waterings,
And so go forth a laureate in hemp circle!

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: You're tart, mine host, and talk above your seasoning,
O'er what you seem: it should not come, methinks ,
Under your cap, this vein of salt, and sharpness!
These strikings upon learning, now and then?
How long have you, (If your dull guest may ask it,)
Drove this quick trade, of keeping the light-heart,
your mansion, palace here, or hostelry.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Troth, I was born to somewhat, sir, above it.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: I easily suspect that: mine host, your name.

sp.speaker: Host
sp.l: They call me good-stock.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: Sir, and you confess it,
Both i'your language, treaty, and your bearing.

sp.speaker: Host
sp.l: Yet all, sir, are not sons o'the white hen;
Nor can we, as the songster says, come all
To be wrapped soft and warm in fortune's smock:
When she is pleased to trick, or trump mankind:
Some may be coats, as in the cards; but, than
Some must be knaves, some varlets, bawds, and ostlers,
As aces, deuces, cards o'ten, to face it
Out, i'the game, which all the world is.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: But,
It being i'your free will (As 'twas) to choose
What parts you would sustain, methinks , a man
Of your sagacity, and clear nostril, should
Have made, another choice, then of a place
So sordid, as the keeping of an inn:
Where every jovial tinker, for his chink,
May cry, mine host, to cram, give us drink;
And do not slink, but skinke, or else you stink.
Rogue, bawd, and cheater, call you by the surnames,
And known synonyma of your profession.

sp.speaker: Host
sp.l: But if I be no such; who then's the rogue,
In understanding, sir, I mean? who errs?
Who tinkleth then? or personates Thom. Tinker?
Your weasel here may tell you I talk bawdy,
And teach my boy it; and you may believe him:
But sir at your own peril, if I do not:
And at his too, if he do lie, and affirm it.
No slander strikes, less hurts, the innocent:
If I be honest, and that all the cheat
Be, of myself, in keeping this light heart,
Where, I imagine all the world's a play;
The state, and men's affairs, all passages
Of life, to spring new, scenes come in, go out,
And shift, and vanish; and if I have got
A seat, to sit at ease here, i' mine inn,
To see the comedy; and laugh, and chuck
At the variety, and throng of humours,
And dispositions, that come justling in,
And out still, as they one drove hence another:
Why, will you envy me my happiness?
Because you are sad, and lumpish; carry a load stone
I'your pocket, to hang knives on; or let-rings,
T'entice light straws to leap at 'em: are not taken
With the alacrities of an host! 'tis more,
And justlier, sir, my wonder, why you took
My house up, fiddler's hall, the seat of noise,
And mirth, an inn here, to be drowsy in,
And lodge your lethargy in the light heart,
As if some cloud from court had been your harbinger,
Or Cheapside debt-books, or some mistress charge,
Seeing your love grow corpulent, give it a diet,
By absence some, such mouldy passion!

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: 'Tis guessed unhappily.

sp.speaker: Fe.
sp.l: Mine host, you're called.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.l: I come, boys.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.l: Ferret have not you been ploughing
With this mad ox, mine host? nor he with you?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: For what sir?

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: Why, to find my riddle out.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: I hope, you do believe, sir, I can find
other discourse to be at, than my master
With hosts, and hostlers.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: If you can, 'tis well.
Go down, and see, who they are come in, what guests;
And bring me word.

div.head: Scene 4.
div.l: O love, what passion art thou!
So tyrannous! and treacherous! first t'enslave,
And then betray, all that in truth do serve thee!
That not the wisest, nor the wariest creature,
Can more dissemble thee, than he can bear
Hot burning coals, in his bare palm, or bosom!
And less, conceal, or hide thee, than a flash
Of inflamed powder, whose whole light doth lay it
Open, to all discovery, even of those,
Who have but half an eye, and less of nose!
An host, to find me! who is, commonly,
The log, a little of this side the signpost!
Or, at the best, some round grown thing! A jug,
Faced, with a beard, that fills out to the guests,
And takes in, fro' the fragments o'their jests?
But, I may wrong this, out of sullenness,
Or my mistaking humour? Pray thee, fantasy,
be laid, again. And, gentle-melancholy,
Do not oppress me. I will be as silent,
As the tame lover should be, and as foolish.

div.head: Scene. 5.
div.l: My guest, my guest, be jovial, I beseech thee.
I' have fresh golden guests, guests o'the game:
Three coachful! Lords! and ladies! new come in.
And I will cry them to thee, and thee, to them,
So I can spring a smile, but this brow,
That like the rugged Roman alderman, —
Old master gross, surnamed 〈◊〉 〈◊〉 〈◊〉.
Was never seen to laugh, but at an ass.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Sir here's the lady Frampul.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: How!

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: And her train.
Lord Beaufort, and lord Latimer, the colonel
Tipto ', with mistress Cis, the chambermaid:
Trundle, the coachman —

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: Stop, discharge the house:
And get my horses ready, bid the groom
Bring 'em to the back gate.

sp.speaker: Host
sp.l: What mean you sir?

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: To take fair leave, mine host.

sp.speaker: Host
sp.l: I hope, my guest,
Though I have talked somewhat above my share,
At large, and been i'the altitudes, th'extravagant,
Neither myself, nor any of mine have gi'n you
The cause, to quit my house, thus, on the sudden,

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: No, I affirm it, on my faith. Excuse me,
from such a rudeness; I was now beginning
To taste, and love you: and am heartily sorry,
Any occasion should be so compelling,
To urge my abrupt departure, thus. But —
Necessity's a tyrant, and commands it.

sp.speaker: Host
sp.l: She shall command me first to fire my bush;
Then break up house: or, if that will not serve,
To break with all the world. Turn country bankrupt.
I' mine own town, upo'the market-day,
And be protested, for my butter, and eggs,
To the last bodge of oats, and bottle of hay;
Ere you shall leave me, I will break my heart:
Coach, and coach-horses, lords, and ladies' pack?
All my fresh guests shall stink! I'll pull my sign, down
Convert mine inn, to an almshouse! or a spittle,
For lazars, or switch-sellers! Turn it, to
An academy o'rogues! or gi' it away
For a free-school, to breed up beggars in,
And send 'em to the canting universities
Before you leave me.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: Troth, and I confess,
I am loath, mine host, to leave you: your expressions
Both take, and hold me. But, in case I stay,
I must enjoin you and your whole family
To privacy, and to conceal me. For,
The secret is, I would not willingly,
See, or be seen, to any of this ging,
Especially, the lady.

sp.speaker: Host
sp.l: Brain o'man,
What monster is she? or cockatrice in velvet,
That kills thus?

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: O good words, mine host. She is
A noble lady! great in blood! and fortune!
Fair! and a wit! but of so bent a fantasy,
As she thinks naught a happiness, but to have
A multitude of servants! and, to get them,
(Though she be very honest) yet she venters
Upon these precipices, that would make her
Not seem so, to some prying, narrow natures.
We call her, sir, the lady Frances Frampul,
Daughter and heir to the lord Frampul.

sp.speaker: Host
sp.l: Who?
He that did love in Oxford, first, a student,
And, after, married with the daughter of —

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: Silly.

sp.speaker: Host
sp.l: Right, of whom the tale went, to turn puppet-master.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: And travel with young goose, the motion-man.

sp.speaker: Host
sp.l: And lie, and live with the Gipsies half a year
Together, from his wife.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: The very same:
The mad lord Frampul! And this same is his daughter!
But as cock-brained as ere the father was!
There were two of 'em, Frances and laetitiae;
But Laetice was lost young; and, as the rumor
Flew then, the mother upon it lost herself.
A fond weak woman, went away in a melancholy,
Because she brought him none but girls, she thought
Her husband loved her not. And he, as foolish,
Too late resenting the cause given, went after;
In quest of her, and was not heard of since.

sp.speaker: Host
sp.l: A strange division of a family!

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: And scattered, as i'the great confusion!

sp.speaker: Host
sp.l: But yet the lady, th'heir, enjoys the land.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: And takes all lordly ways how to consume it
As nobly as she can; if clothes, and feasting,
And the authorised means of riot will do it.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: She shows her extract, and I honour her for it.

div.head: Scene. 6
div.l: Your horse's sir are ready; and the house
Dis -

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: Pleased, thou thinkst?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: I cannot tell, discharged
I'm sure it is.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: Charge it again, good ferret.
And make unready the horses: thou knowest how.
Chalk, and renew the rondels. I am, now
Resolved to stay.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: I easily thought so,
When you should hear what's purposed.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.l: What?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: To throw
The house out o'the windo?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Brain o'man,
I shall ha'the worst o'that! will they not throw
My household stuff out, first? Cushions, and carpets,
Chairs, stools, and bedding? is not their sport my ruin?

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: Fear not, mine host, I am not o'the fellowship.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: I cannot see, sir, how you will avoid it;
They know already all, you are i'the house.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: Who know?

sp.speaker: F.
sp.l: The lords: they have seen me, and enquired it.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: Why were you seeney

sp.speaker: Fer
sp.l: Because indeed I had
No medicine, sir, to go invisible:
No fern-seed in my pocket; nor an opal
Wrapped in a bay-leaf, i'my left fist,
To charm their eyes with.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.l: He dos give you reasons
As round as Gyges' ring: which, say the ancients,
Was a hoop ring; and that is, round as a hoop!

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: You will ha' your rebus still, mine host.

sp.speaker: Host
sp.l: I must:

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: My lady, too, looked out o'the windo, and called me.
And see where secretary

sp.speaker: Prudence
sp.l: Comes from her,
Employed upon some embassy unto you —

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: I'll meet her, if she come upon employment;
Fair lady, welcome, as your host can make you.

sp.speaker: Prudence
sp.l: Forbear, sir, I am first to have mine audience,
Before the compliment. This gentleman
Is my address to.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: And it is in state.

sp.speaker: Prudence
sp.l: My lady, sir, as glad o'the encounter
To find a servant, here, and such a servant,
Whom she so values; with her best respects,
Desires to be remembered: and invites
Your nobleness, to be a part, today,
Of the society, and mirth intended
By her, and the young lords, your fellow-servants.
Who are alike ambitious of enjoying
The fair request; and to that end have sent
Me, their imperfect orator, to obtain it:
Which if I may, they have elected me,
And crowned me, with the title of a sovereign
Of the day's sports devised i'the inn,
So you be pleased to add your suffrage to it.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: So I be pleased, my gentle mistress prudence?
You cannot think me of that course condition,
T'envy you any thing.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: That's nobly said!
And like my guest!

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: I gratulate your honour;
And should, with cheer, lay hold on any handle,
That could advance it. But for me to think,
I can be any rag, or particle
o'your lady's care, more than to fill her list,
She being the lady, that professeth still
To love no soul, or body, but for ends;
Which are her sports: and is not nice to speak this,
But doth proclaim it, in all companies:
Her ladyship must pardon my weak counsels,
And weaker will, if it decline t'obey her.

sp.speaker: Prudence
sp.l: O master Lovel you must not give credit
To all that ladies publicly profess,
Or talk, o'th vollee, unto their servants.
Their tongues and thoughts, oft times lie far asunder.
Yet, when they please, they have their cabinet-counsels
And reserved thoughts, and can retire themselves
As well as others.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Ay, the subtlest of us!
All that is born within a lady's lips —

sp.speaker: Prudence
sp.l: Is not the issue of their hearts, mine host.

sp.speaker: Host
sp.l: Or kiss, or drink afore me.

sp.speaker: Prudence
sp.l: Stay, excuse me;
Mine errand is not done. Yet, if her ladyships
Slighting, or disesteem, sir, of your service,
Hath formerly begotten any distaste,
Which I not know of: here, I vow unto you,
Upon a chambermaid's simplicity,
Reserving, still, the honour of my lady,
I will be bold to hold the glass up to her,
To show her ladyship where she hath erred,
And how to tender satisfaction:
So you vouchsafe to prove, but the day's venture.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: What say you, sir? where are you? are you within?

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: Yes: I will wait upon her, and the company.

sp.speaker: Host
sp.l: It is enough, Queen prudence; I will bring him:
and, o'this kiss. I longed to kiss a Queen!

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: There is no life on earth, but being in love!
There are no studies, no delights, no business,
No intercourse, or trade of sense, or soul,
But what is love! I was the laziest creature,
The most unprofitable sign of nothing,
The veriest drone, and slept away my life
Beyond the dormouse, till I was in love!
And, now, I can out-wake the nightingale,
Outwatch an usurer, and outwalk him too,
Stalk like a ghost, that haunted bout a treasure,
And all that fancied treasure, it is love!

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: But is your name Love-ill, sir, or Lovewell?
I would know that.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: I do not know't myself,
Whether it is. But it is love hath been
The hereditary passion of our house,
My gentle host, and, as I guess, my friend;
The truth is, I have loved this lady long,
And impotently, with desire enough,
But no success: for I have still forborn
To express it, in my person, to her.

sp.speaker: Host
sp.l: How then?

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: I ha' sent her toys, verses, and anagrams,
Trials of wit, mere trifles she has commended,
But knew not whence they came, nor could she guess.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: This was a pretty riddling way of wooing!

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: I oft have been, too, in her company;
And looked upon her, a whole day; admired her;
Loved her, and did not tell her so; loved still,
Looked still, and loved: and loved, and looked, and sighed;
But, as a man neglected, I came of,
and unregarded —

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Could you blame her, sir,
When you were silent, and not said a word?

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: O but I loved the more; and she might read it
Best, in my silence, had she been —

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: As melancholic
As you are. Pray you, why would you stand mute, sir?

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: O thereon hangs a history, mine host.
Did you ever know, or hear, of the lord Beaufort,
Who served so bravely in France? I was his page,
And, ere he died, his friend! I followed him,
First, i'the wars; and i'the times of peace,
I waited on his studies: which were right.
He had no Arthur's, nor no rosicleer's,
No knights o'the sun, nor Amadis de Gaule's,
Primaleon's, and Pantagruel's, public nothings;
Abortives of the fabulous, dark cloister,
Sent out to poison courts, and infest manners:
But great Achilles, Agamemnon's acts,
Sage Nestor's counsels, and Ulysses' slights,
Tydides' fortitude, as Homer wrought them
In his immortal fantasy, for examples
Of the heroic virtue. Or, as Virgil,
That master of the epic poem, limned
Pious Aeneas, his religious prince,
Bearing his aged parent on his shoulders,
Rapt from the flames of Troy, with his young son.
And these he brought to practise, and to use.
He gave me first my breeding, I acknowledge,
Then showered his bounties on me, like the hours,
That openhanded sit upon the clouds,
And press the liberality of heaven
down to the laps of thankful men! But then!
The trust committed to me, at his death,
Was above all! and left so strong a tie
On all my powers! as time shall not dissolve!
Till it dissolve itself, and bury all!
The care of his brave heir, and only son!
Who being a virtuous, sweet, young, hopeful lord,
Hath cast his first affections on this lady.
And though I know, and may presume her such,
As, out of humour, will return no love;
And therefore might indifferently be made
The courting-stock, for all to practise on.
As she doth practise on all us, to scorn:
Yet, out of a religion to my charge,
And debt professed, I ha' made a self-decree,
Ne'er to express my person; though my passion
Burn me to cinders.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Then you're not so subtle,
Or half so read in love-craft, as I took you.
Come, come, you are no phoenix, an' you were,
I should expect no miracle from your ashes.
Take some advice. Be still that rag of love,
You are. Burn on till you turn tinder.
This chambermaid may hap to prove the steel,
To strike a sparkle out o'the flint, your mistress
May beget bonfires yet, you do not know,
What light may be forced out, and from what darkness.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: Nay, I am so resolved, as still I'll love
Though not confess it.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: That's, sir, as it chances:
We'll throw the dice for it: cheer up.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: I do.

div.head: Scene 1.
div.l: Come wench, this suit will serve: dispatch, make ready.
It was a great deal with the biggest for me;
Which made me leave it off after once wearing.
How does it fit? wilt come together?

sp.speaker: Prudence
sp.l: Hardly.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Thou must make shift with it. Pride feels no pain●
Girt thee hard,

sp.speaker: Prudence
sp.l: Pox of this errand Taylour,
He angers me beyond all mark of patience.
These base mechanics never keep their word,
In any thing they promise. Pru. 'tis their trade, madam;
To swear and break, they all grow rich by breaking,
More than their words; their honesties, and credits,
Are still the first commodity they put off.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: And worst, it seems, which makes them do't so often.
If he had but broken with me, I had not cared,
But, with the company, the body politic -

sp.speaker: Prudence
sp.l: Frustrate our whole design, having that time,
And the materials in so long before?

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: And he to fail in all, and disappoint us?
The rogue deserves a torture -

sp.speaker: Prudence
sp.l: To be cropped
With his own scissors.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Let's devise him one.

sp.speaker: Prudence
sp.l: And ha' the stumps seared up with his own searing candle?

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Close to his head, to trundle on his pillow?
I'll ha' the lease of his house cut out in measures.

sp.speaker: Prudence
sp.l: And he be strangled with 'em?

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: No, no life
I would ha'touch't, but stretched on his own yard
He should be a little, ha' the strappado?

sp.speaker: Prudence
sp.l: Or an ell of taffeta
Drawn thorough his guts, by way of glister, and fired
With aqua vitae?

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Burning i'the hand
With the pressing iron cannot save him.

sp.speaker: Prudence
sp.l: Yes,
Now I have got this on: I do forgive him,
What robes he should ha' brought.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Thou art not cruel,
Although straitlaced, I see, Pru!

sp.speaker: Prudence
sp.l: This is well.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: 'Tis rich enough! But 'tis not what I meant thee!
I would ha' had thee braver than myself,
And brighter far. 'twill fit the players yet,
When thou hast done with it, and yield thee somewhat.

sp.speaker: Prudence
sp.l: That were illiberal, madam, and mere sordid
In me, to let a suit of yours come there.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Tut, all are players, and but serve the scene. Pru,
Dispatch; I fear thou dost not like the province,
Thou art so long a fitting thyself for it.
Here is a scarf, to make thee a knot finer.

sp.speaker: Prudence
sp.l: You send me a feasting, madam.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Wear it wench

sp.speaker: Prudence
sp.l: Yes. but, with leave o'your ladyship, I would tell you
This can but bear the face of an odd journey.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Why Pru?

sp.speaker: Prudence
sp.l: A lady of your rank and quality,
To come to a public inn, so many men,
Young lords, and others, i'your company!
And not a woman but myself, a chambermaid!

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Thou doubt'st to be overlaid Pru? Fear it not,
I le bear my part, and share with thee, i'the venture.

sp.speaker: Prudence
sp.l: O but the censure, madam, is the main,
What will they say of you? or judge of me?
To be translated thus, 'bove all the bound
Of fitness, or decorum?

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: How, now! Pru!
Turned fool upo'the sudden, and talk idly
I'thy best clothes! shoot bolts, and sentences
T'affright babies with? as if I lived
To any other scale than what's my own?
Or sought myself, without myself, from home?

sp.speaker: Prudence
sp.l: Your ladyship will pardon me, my fault,
If I have overshot, I'll shoot no more.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Yes shoot again, good Pru, I'll ha' thee shoot,
And aim, and hit: I know 'tis love in thee,
And so I do interpret it.

sp.speaker: Prudence
sp.l: Then madam,
I'd crave a farther leave.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Be it to licence,
It sha'not want an ear, Pru, say, what is it?

sp.speaker: Prudence
sp.l: A toy I have, to raise a little mirth,
To the design in hand.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Out with it Pru.
If it but chime of mirth.

sp.speaker: Prudence
sp.l: Mine host has, madam,
A pretty boy i'the house, a dainty child,
His son, and is o'your ladyship's name too, Frances,
Whom if your ladyship would borrow of him,
And give me leave to dress him, as I would,
Should make the finest lady, and kinswoman,
To keep you company, and deceive my lords,
Upo'the matter, with a fountain o'sport.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: I apprehend thee, and the source of mirth
That it may breed, but is he bold enough,
The child? and well assured?

sp.speaker: Prudence
sp.l: As I am, madam,
Have him in no suspicion, more than me:
Here comes mine host: will you but please to ask him,
Or let me make the motion?

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Which thou wilt, Pr●

div.head: Scene 2.
div.l: Your ladyship, and all your train are welcome.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: I thank my hearty host.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: So is your sovereignty,
Madam, I wish you joy o'your new gown.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: It should ha' been, my host, but stuff, our tailor
Has broke with us, you shall be o'the counsel.

sp.speaker: Prudence
sp.l: He will deserve it, madame, my lady has heard
You have a pretty son, mine host, she'd see him.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: I very fain, I pray thee let me see him, host.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Your ladyship shall presently,
Bid Frank come hither, anon, unto my lady,
It is a bashful child, homely brought up,
In a rude hostelry. But the light heart
Is his fathers, and it may be his.
Here he comes. Frank salute my lady.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: I do.
What, madam, I am designed to do, by my birth right,
As heir of the light heart, bid you most welcome.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: And I believe your most, my pretty boy,
Being so emphased, by you.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Your ladyship,
If you believe it such, are sure to make it.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Prettily answered! Is your name Francis?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Yes madam.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: I love mine own the better.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: If I knew yours,
I should make haste to do so too, good madam.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: It is the same with yours.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.l: Mine then acknowledgeth
the lustre it receives, by being named, after.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: You will win upon me in compliment.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: By silence.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: A modest, and a fair well spoken-child.

sp.speaker: Host
sp.l: Her ladyship, shall have him, sovereign Pru,
Or what I have beside: divide my heart,
Between you and your lady. Make your use of it:
My house is yours, my son is yours. Behold,
I tender him to your service; Frank, become
What these brave ladies would ha' you. Only this,
There is a charwoman i'the house, his nurse,
An Irish woman, I took in, a beggar,
That waits upon him; a poor silly fool,
But an impertinent, and sedulous one,
As ever was: will vex you on all occasions,
Never be off, or from you, but in her sleep;
Or drink which makes it. She doth love him so,
Or rather dote on him. Now, for her, a shape,
As we may dress her (And I'll help) to fit her,
With a tuft-taffata cloak, an old French hood,
And other pieces, heterogene enough.

sp.speaker: Prudence
sp.l: We ha' brought a standard of apparel, down,
Because this tailor ●ayld us i'the main.

sp.speaker: Host
sp.l: She shall advance the game.

sp.speaker: Prudence
sp.l: About it then.
And send but trundle, hither, the coachman, to me.

sp.speaker: Host
sp.l: I shall: but Pru, let Lovel ha' fair quarter.

sp.speaker: Prudence
sp.l: The best.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Our host ( methinks ) is very game some!

sp.speaker: Prudence
sp.l: How like you the boy?

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: A miracle!

sp.speaker: Prudence
sp.l: Good madam
But take him in, and sort a suit for him,
We give our trundle his instructions;
And wait upon your ladyship, i'the instant.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: But Pru, what shall we call him, when we ha' dressed him?

sp.speaker: Prudence
sp.l: My lady-nobody, any thing what you will.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Call him Laetitia, by my sister's name,
And so 'twill mind our mirth too, we have in hand.

div.head: Scene. 3.
div.l: Good trundle, you must straight make ready the coach,
And lead the horses out but half a mile,
Into the fields, whether you will, and then
Drive in again, with the coach-leaves put down,
At the back gate, and so to the back stairs,
As if you brought in somebody , to my lady,
A kinswoman, that she sent for, make that answer
If you be asked; and give it out o'th' house, so.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.l: What trick is this, good mistress secretary,
You'd put upon us?

sp.speaker: Prudence
sp.l: Us? Do you speak plural?

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.l: Me and my mares are us.

sp.speaker: Prudence
sp.l: If you so join 'em.
Elegant trundle, you may use your figures.
I can but urge, it is my lady's service.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.l: Good mistress prudence, you can urge enough.
I know you are secretary to my lady,
And mistress steward.

sp.speaker: Prudence
sp.l: You'll still be trundling,
And ha' your wages stopped, now at the audite.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.l: 'Tis true, you are gentlewoman o'the horse too.
Or what you will beside, Pru, I do think it:
my best to obey you.

sp.speaker: Prudence
sp.l: And I think so too, trundle.

div.head: Scene. 4.
div.l: Why here's return enough of both our venters,
If we do make no more discovery.

sp.speaker: Lat.
sp.l: What?
Then of this parasite?

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: O he's a dainty one.
The parasite of the house.

sp.speaker: Lat.
sp.l: Here comes mine host.

sp.speaker: Host
sp.l: My lords, you both are welcome to the heart.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: To the light heart we hope.

sp.speaker: Lat.
sp.l: And merry I swear.
We never yet felt such a fit of laughter,
As your glad heart hath offered us, sin' we entered.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: How came you by this property?

sp.speaker: Host
sp.l: Who! my fly!

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Your fly if you call him so.

sp.speaker: Host
sp.l: Nay, he is that.
And will be still.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: In every dish and pot?

sp.speaker: Host
sp.l: In every cup, and company, my lords,
A creature of all liquours, all complexions,
Be the drink what it will, he'll have his sip.

sp.speaker: Lat.
sp.l: He's fitted with a name.

sp.speaker: Host
sp.l: And he joys in't:
I had him when I came to take the inn, here,
Assigned me over, in the inventory,
As an old implement, a piece of householdstuff,
And so he doth remain.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Just such a thing,
We thought him,

sp.speaker: Lat.
sp.l: Is he a scholar?

sp.speaker: Host
sp.l: Nothing less.
But colours for it, as you see: wears black;
And speaks a little tainted, fly-blown Latin,
after the school.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Of Stratford of the bow.
For lilies Latin, is to him unknown.

sp.speaker: Lat.
sp.l: What calling 'He?

sp.speaker: Host
sp.l: Only to call in, still.
Inflame the reckoning, bold to charge a bill,
Bring up the shot i'the rear, as his own word is,

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: And does it in the discipline of the house?
As corporal of the field, maestro deal Campo,

sp.speaker: Host
sp.l: And visitor general, of all the room,
He has formed a fine militia for the inn too.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: And means to publish it?

sp.speaker: Host
sp.l: With all his titles.
Some call him deacon fly, some doctor fly.
Some captain, some lieutenant, but my folks
Do call him quartermaster, fly, which he is.

div.head: Scene. 5.
div.stage: Tipto. Host. Flie. l. Bea. l. Lati.
div.l: Come quartermaster fly.

sp.speaker: Host
sp.l: Here's one, already,
Hath got his titles.

sp.speaker: Tip.
sp.l: Doctor!

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: Noble colonel!
No doctor, yet. A poor professor of ceremony,
Here i'the inn, retainer to the host,
I discipline the house.

sp.speaker: Tip.
sp.l: Thou readest a lecture.
Unto the family here, when is the day?

sp.speaker: Fli.
sp.l: This is the day.

sp.speaker: Tip.
sp.l: I'll hear thee, and I'll ha'thee a doctor,
Thou shalt be one, thou hast a doctor's look!
A face disputative, of Salamanca.

sp.speaker: Host
sp.l: Who's this?

sp.speaker: Lat.
sp.l: The glorious colonel Tipto, host,

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: One talks upon his tiptoes, if you'll hear him.

sp.speaker: Tip.
sp.l: Thou hast good learning in thee, macte fly.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: And I say macte, to my colonel.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Well macted of'hem both.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: They are matched i'faith.

sp.speaker: Tip.
sp.l: But fly, why macte?

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: Quasi magis ancte,
My honourable colonel.

sp.speaker: Tip.
sp.l: What a critic?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: There's another accession, critic fly.

sp.speaker: Lat.
sp.l: I fear a taint here i'the mathematics.
They say, lines parallel do never meet;
He has met his parallel in wit, and school-craft.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: They side, not meet man, mend your metaphor,
And save the credit of your mathematics.

sp.speaker: Tip.
sp.l: But fly, how cam'st thou to be here, committed
Unto this inn? Fly, upon suspicion o'drink, sir,
I was taken late one night, here, with the tapster,
And the under-officers, and so deposited.

sp.speaker: Tip.
sp.l: I will redeem thee, fly, and place thee better,
With a fair lady.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: A lady, sweet sir glorious!

sp.speaker: Tip.
sp.l: A sovereign lady. Thou shalt be the bird
To sovereign Pru, Queen of our sports, her fly,
The fly in household, and in ordinary;
Bird of her care, and she shall wear thee there!
A fly of gold, enamelled, and a school-fly.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: The school, then are my stables, or the cellar,
Where he doth study, deeply, at his hours,
Cases of cups, I do not know how spiced
With conscience, for the tapster, and the ostler: as
Whose horses may be cozened? or what jugs
Filled up with froth? that is his way of learning,

sp.speaker: Tip.
sp.l: What antiquated father's that, that talks?

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: The worshipful host, my patron, Mr. good-stock:
A merry Greek, and cants in Latin, comely.
Spins like the parish top.

sp.speaker: Tip.
sp.l: I'll set him up, then.
Art thou the dominus?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Factotum here, sir.

sp.speaker: Tip.
sp.l: Host real o'the house? and cap of maintenance?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: The lord o'the light heart, sir, cap a pie;
Whereof the feather is the emblem, colonel,
Put up, with the ace of hearts!

sp.speaker: Tip.
sp.l: But why in cuerpo?
I hate to see an host, and old, in cuerpo.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Cuerpo? what's that?

sp.speaker: Tip.
sp.l: Light, skipping hose and doublet,
The horse boys garb! poor blank, and half blank cuerpo,
They relish not the gravity of an host,
Who should be King at arms, and ceremonies,
In his own house! know all, to the goldweights.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Why that his fly doth for him here, your bird.

sp.speaker: Tip.
sp.l: But I would do it myself, were I my host,
I would not speak unto a cook of quality,
Your lordship's footman, or my lady's trundle,
In cuerpo! If a dog but stayed below
That were a dog of fashion, and well nosed,
And could present himself; I would put on
The Savoy chain about my neck; the ruff;
And cuffs of Flanders; then the Naples hat;
With the Rome hatband; and the Florentine agate;
The Milan sword; the cloak of Genoa; set
With Brabant buttons; all my given pieces:
Except my gloves, the natives of Madrid,
To entertain him in! and compliment
With a tame coney, as with a prince that sent it.

sp.speaker: Host
sp.l: The same deeds, though, become not every man,
That fits a colonel, will not fit an host,

sp.speaker: Tip.
sp.l: Your Spanish host is never seen in cuerpo,
Without his Paramento's cloak, and sword.

sp.speaker: Fli.
sp.l: Sir he has the father
Of swords, within a long sword; blade Cornish styled
Of sir Rud Hughdibras.

sp.speaker: Tip.
sp.l: And with a long sword, bully bird? thy sense?

sp.speaker: Fli.
sp.l: To note him a tall-man, and a master offence:

sp.speaker: Tip.
sp.l: But doth he teach the Spanish way of don Lewis?

sp.speaker: Fli.
sp.l: No, the Greek master he.

sp.speaker: Tip.
sp.l: What call you him?

sp.speaker: Fli.
sp.l: Euclid.

sp.speaker: Tip.
sp.l: Fart upon Euclid, he is stale, and antique,
Gi'me the moderns.

sp.speaker: Fli.
sp.l: Sir he minds no moderns,
Go by, Hieronymo!

sp.speaker: Tip.
sp.l: What was he?

sp.speaker: Fli.
sp.l: The Italian,
That played with abbot Antony, i'the friars,
And blinkin-sops the bold.

sp.speaker: Tip.
sp.l: I marry, those,
Had fencing names, what's become o'them?

sp.speaker: Host
sp.l: They had their times, and we can say, they were
So had caranza-his: so had don Lewis.

sp.speaker: Tip.
sp.l: Don Lewis of Madrid, is the sole master
Now, of the world.

sp.speaker: Host
sp.l: But this, of the other world
Euclid demonstrates! he! He's for all!
The only fencer of name, now in Elysium.

sp.speaker: Fli.
sp.l: He does it all, by lines, and angles, colonel.
By parallels, and sections, has his diagrams!

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Wilt thou be flying, fly?

sp.speaker: Lat.
sp.l: At all, why not?
The air's as free for a fly, as for an eagle.

sp.speaker: Bea
sp.l: A buzzard! he is in his contemplation!

sp.speaker: Tip.
sp.l: Euclid a fencer, and in the Elysium!

sp.speaker: Host
sp.l: He played a prize, last week, with Archimedes,
And beat him I assure you.

sp.speaker: Tip.
sp.l: Do you assure me?
For what?

sp.speaker: Host
sp.l: For four i'the hundred. Gi'me five,
And I assure you, again.

sp.speaker: Tip.
sp.l: Host, peremptory,
You may be ta'en, but where? whence had you this?

sp.speaker: Host
sp.l: Upo'the road, a post, that came from thence,
Three days ago, here, left it with the tapster.

sp.speaker: Fli.
sp.l: Who is indeed a thorough fare of news,
Jack jug with the broken belly, a witty fellow!

sp.speaker: Host
sp.l: Your bird here heard him.

sp.speaker: Tip.
sp.l: Did you hear him bird?

sp.speaker: Host
sp.l: Speak i'the faith of a fly.

sp.speaker: Fli.
sp.l: Yes, and he told us,
Of one that was the prince of Orange's fencer,

sp.speaker: Tip.
sp.l: Stevinus?

sp.speaker: Fli.
sp.l: Sir the same, had challenged Euclid
A thirty weapons more than Archimedes
E'er saw; and engines: most of his own invention:

sp.speaker: Tip.
sp.l: This may have credit, and chimes reason, this!
If any man endanger Euclid, bird,
Observe, that had the honour to quit Europe
This forty year, 'tis he. He put down Scaliger.

sp.speaker: Fli.
sp.l: And he was a great master.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Not of fence, fly.

sp.speaker: Tip.
sp.l: Excuse him, lord, he went of the same grounds.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: On the same earth I think, with other mortals?

sp.speaker: Tip.
sp.l: I mean, sweet lord, the mathematics. Basta!
When thou knowest more, thou wilt take less, green honour.
He had his circles, semicircles, quadrants —

sp.speaker: Fli.
sp.l: He writ a book of the quadrature of the circle,

sp.speaker: Tip.
sp.l: Cyclometria, I read —

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: The title only.

sp.speaker: Lat.
sp.l: And indice.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: If it had one of that quare
What insolent, half-witted things, these are?

sp.speaker: Lat.
sp.l: So are all smatterers, insolent, and impudent.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: They lightly go together.

sp.speaker: Lat.
sp.l: 'Tis my wonder!
Two animals should hawk at all discourse thus!
Fly every subject to the mark, or retrieve —

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: And never ha' the luck to be i'the right!

sp.speaker: Lat.
sp.l: 'Tis foam folks fortune!

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Fortune's a bawd
And a blind beggar: 'tis their vanity!
And shows most vilely!

sp.speaker: Tip.
sp.l: I could take the heart now.
To write unto don Lewis, into Spain,
To make a progress to the Elysian fields,
Next summer —

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: And persuade him die for same,
Of fencing with a shadow! Where's mine host?
I would he had heard this bubble break, i'fayth.

div.head: Scene 6.
div.stage: Host. Ti●. Prudence. Beaufort. Latimer. Frank. Nurse. Lady. Flie. Lovel.
div.l: Make place, stand by, for the Queen regent, gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Tip.
sp.l: This is thy Queen, that shall be, bird, our sovereign.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Translated prudence!

sp.speaker: Prudence
sp.l: Sweet my lord, hand off;
It is not now, as when plain prudence lived,
And reached her ladyship —

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: The chamber-pot.

sp.speaker: Prudence
sp.l: The lookingglass, mine host, lose your house metaphor
You have a negligent memory, indeed;
Speak the host's language. Here's a young lord,
Will make't a precedent else.

sp.speaker: Lat.
sp.l: Well acted Pru.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: First minute of her reign! what will she do
Forty year hence? God bless her!

sp.speaker: Prudence
sp.l: If you'll kiss,
Or compliment, my lord, behold a lady,
A stranger, and my lady's kinswoman.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: I do confess my rudeness, that had need
To have mine eye directed to this beauty.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: It was so little, as it asked a perspicil.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Lady, your name?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: My lord, it is Laetitia.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Laetitia! A fair omen! And I take it.
Let me have still such lettuce for my lips:
But that of your family, lady?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Silly, sir.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: My lady's kinswoman?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: I am so honoured.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Already, it takes!

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: An excellent fine boy.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: He is descended of a right good stock, sir.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: What's this? an antiquary?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: An antiquity,
By th' dress, you'd swear! An old Welsh herald's widow:
She's a Wild-irish born! Sir, and a hybrid,
That lives with this young lady, a mile off here,
And studies Vincent against York.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: She'll conquer,
If she read Vincent. Let me study her.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: She's perfect in most pedigrees, most descents.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: A bawd, I hope, and knows to blaze a coat.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: And judgeth all things with a single eye,
Fly, come you hither; no discovery
Of what you see, to your colonel toe, or tip, here,
But keep all close, tho' you stand i'the way o'preferment,
seek it, off from the road; no flattery for't:
No lick-foot, pain of losing your proboscis:
My liquorish fly.

sp.speaker: Tip.
sp.l: What says old velvet-head?

sp.speaker: Fli.
sp.l: He will present me himself, sir, if you will not.

sp.speaker: Tip.
sp.l: Who? he present? what? whom? An host? A groom?
Divide the thanks with me? share in my glories?
Lay up. I say no more.

sp.speaker: Host
sp.l: Then silence sir,
And hear the sovereign.

sp.speaker: Tip.
sp.l: Ostlers? to usurp
Upon my Sparta or province, as they say?
No broom but mine?

sp.speaker: Host
sp.l: Still colonel, you mutter?

sp.speaker: Tip.
sp.l: I dare speak out, as cuerpo.

sp.speaker: Fli.
sp.l: Noble colonel.

sp.speaker: Tip.
sp.l: And carry what I ask -

sp.speaker: Host
sp.l: Ask what you can sir
So't be i'the house.

sp.speaker: Tip.
sp.l: I ask my rights and privileges,
And though for form I please to cal't a suit,
I have not been accustomed to repulse.

sp.speaker: Prudence
sp.l: No sweet sir glorious, you may still command.

sp.speaker: Host
sp.l: And go without.

sp.speaker: Prudence
sp.l: But yet sir being the first,
And called a suit, you'll look it shall be such
As we may grant.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: It else denies itself.

sp.speaker: Prudence
sp.l: You hear the opinion of the court.

sp.speaker: Tip.
sp.l: I mind
No court opinions.

sp.speaker: Prudence
sp.l: 'Tis my ladies, though.

sp.speaker: Tip.
sp.l: My lady is a spinster, at the law,
And my petition is of right.

sp.speaker: Prudence
sp.l: What is it?

sp.speaker: Tip.
sp.l: It is for this poor learned bird.

sp.speaker: Host
sp.l: The fly?

sp.speaker: Tip.
sp.l: Professor in the inn, here, of small matters:

sp.speaker: Lat.
sp.l: How he commends him!

sp.speaker: Host
sp.l: As, to save himself ●n him.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: So do all politics in their commendations.

sp.speaker: Host
sp.l: This is a state-bird, and the verier fly?

sp.speaker: Tip.
sp.l: Hear him problematize.

sp.speaker: Prudence
sp.l: Bless us, what's that?

sp.speaker: Tip.
sp.l: Or syllogize, elenchize.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Sure, petards,
To blow us up.

sp.speaker: Lat.
sp.l: Some ingenious strong words!

sp.speaker: Host
sp.l: He means to erect a castle i'the air,
And make his fly an elephant to carry it.

sp.speaker: Tip.
sp.l: Bird of the arts he is, and fly by name!

sp.speaker: Prudence
sp.l: Buz.

sp.speaker: Host
sp.l: Blow him off good Pru, they'll mar all else.

sp.speaker: Tip.
sp.l: The sovereign's honour is to cherish learning.

sp.speaker: Prudence
sp.l: What in a fly?

sp.speaker: Tip.
sp.l: In any thing industrious.

sp.speaker: Prudence
sp.l: But flies are busy!

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Nothing more troublesome,
Or importune!

sp.speaker: Tip.
sp.l: There's nothing more domestic,
Tame, or familiar than your fly in cuerpo.

sp.speaker: Host
sp.l: That is when his wings are cut, he is tame indeed, else
Nothing more impudent, and greedy; licking:

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Or saucy, good sir glorious.

sp.speaker: Prudence
sp.l: Leave your advocateship
Except that we shall call you orator fly,
And send you down to the dresser, and the dishes.

sp.speaker: Host
sp.l: A good flap, that!

sp.speaker: Prudence
sp.l: Commit you to the steem!

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Or ●s condemn you to the bottles.

sp.speaker: Prudence
sp.l: And pots.
There is his quarry.

sp.speaker: Host
sp.l: He will chirp, far better,
Your bird, below.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: And make you finer music.

sp.speaker: Prudence
sp.l: His buzz will there become him.

sp.speaker: Tip.
sp.l: Come away.
Buz, in their faces: give 'em all the buz,
Dor in their ears, and eyes, hum, dor, and Buz!
I will statuminate and under prop thee.
If they scorn us, let us scorn them - we'll find
The thoroughfare below, and quaere him,
Leave these relics, buz; they shall see that I,
Spite of their jeers, dare drink, and with a fly.

sp.speaker: Lat.
sp.l: A fair remove at once, of two impertinents!
Excellent Pru! I love thee for thy wit,
No less than state.

sp.speaker: Prudence
sp.l: One must preserve the other.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Who's here?

sp.speaker: Prudence
sp.l: O Lovel, madam, your sad servant.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Sad? he is sullen still, and wears a cloud
About his brows; I know not how to approach him.

sp.speaker: Prudence
sp.l: I will instruct you, madam, if that be all,
Go to him and kiss him.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: How, Pru?

sp.speaker: Prudence
sp.l: Go, and kiss him,
I do command it.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Thou'rt not wild, wench!

sp.speaker: Prudence
sp.l: No,
Tame, and exceeding tame, but still your sovereign.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Hath too much bravery made thee mad?

sp.speaker: Prudence
sp.l: Nor proud
Doe, what I do enjoin you. No disputing
Of my prerogative, with a front, or frown;
Do not detract: you know th'authority
Is mine, and I will exercise it, swiftly,
If you provoke me.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: I have woven a net
To snare myself in! Sir I am enjoined
To tender you a kiss; but do not know
Why, or wherefore, only the pleasure royal
Will have it so, and urges — do not you
Triumph on my obedience, seeing it forced thus.
There 'tis.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: And welcome. Was there ever kiss
That relished thus! or had a sting like this,
Of so much nectar, but, with aloës mixed.

sp.speaker: Prudence
sp.l: No murmuring, nor repining, I am fixed.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: It had, methinks , a quintessence of either,
But that which was the better, drowned the bitter.
How soon it passed away! how unrecover!
The distillation of another soul
Was not so sweet! and till I meet again,
that kiss, those lips, like relish, and this taste,
Let me turn all, consumption, and, here waste.

sp.speaker: Prudence
sp.l: The royal assent is past, and cannot alter.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: You'll turn a tyrant.

sp.speaker: Prudence
sp.l: Be not you a rebel,
It is a name is alike odious.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: You'll hear me?

sp.speaker: Prudence
sp.l: No, not o'this argument.
Would you make laws, and be the first that break 'em?
The example is pernicious in a subject,
And of your quality, most.

sp.speaker: Lat.
sp.l: Excellent Princess!

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Just Queen!

sp.speaker: Lat.
sp.l: Brave sovereign.

sp.speaker: Host
sp.l: A she-troyan! this!

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: What is't? Proceed incomparable Pru!
I am glad I am scarce at leisure to applaud thee.

sp.speaker: Lat.
sp.l: It's well for you, you have so happy expressions.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Yes, cry her up, with acclamations, do,
And cry me down, run all with sovereignty.
Prince power will never want her parasites.

sp.speaker: Prudence
sp.l: Nor murmur her pretences: master Lovel,
For so your libel here, or bill of complaint,
Exhibited, in our high court of sovereignty,
At this first hour of our reign, declares
Against this noble lady, a disrespect
You have conceived, if not received, from her.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Received, so the charge lies in our bill.

sp.speaker: Prudence
sp.l: We see it, his learned council, leave your planing,
We that do love our justice, above all
Our other attributes; and have the nearness,
To know your extraordinary merit;
As also to discern this lady's goodness;
And find how loath she'd be, to lose the honour,
and reputation, she hath had, in having
So worthy a servant, though but for few minutes.
Do here enjoin.

sp.speaker: Host
sp.l: Good!

sp.speaker: Prudence
sp.l: Charge, will, and command
Her ladyship, pain of our high displeasure
And the committing an extreme contempt,
Unto the court, our crown and dignity.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Excellent sovereign! And egregious Pru●

sp.speaker: Prudence
sp.l: To entertain you for a pair of hours,
(Choose, when you please, this day) with all respects,
And valuation of a principal servant,
To give you all the titles, all the privileges,
The freedoms, favours, rights, she can bestow.

sp.speaker: Host
sp.l: Large, ample words, of a brave latitude!

sp.speaker: Prudence
sp.l: Or can be expected, from a lady of honour,
Or quality, in discourse, access, address.

sp.speaker: Host
sp.l: Good.

sp.speaker: Prudence
sp.l: Not to give ear, or admit conference
With any person but yourself. Nor there,
Of any other argument, but love,
And the companion of it, gentile courtship.
For which your two hours service, you shall take
Two kisses.

sp.speaker: Host
sp.l: Noble!

sp.speaker: Prudence
sp.l: For each hour, a kiss,
To be ta'en freely, fully, and legally;
Before us; in the court here, and our presence.

sp.speaker: Host
sp.l: Rare?

sp.speaker: Prudence
sp.l: But those hours past, and the two kisses paid,
The binding caution is, never to hope
Renewing of the time, or of the suit,
On any circumstance.

sp.speaker: Host
sp.l: A hard condition!

sp.speaker: Lat.
sp.l: Had it been easier, I should have suspected
The sovereign's justice.

sp.speaker: Host
sp.l: O you are servant,
My lord, unto the lady, and a rival:
in point of law, my lord, you may be challenged.

sp.speaker: Lat.
sp.l: I am not jealous!

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Of so short a time
Your lordship needs not, and being done, in foro.

sp.speaker: Prudence
sp.l: What is the answer?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: He craves respite, madam,
To advise with his learned council.

sp.speaker: Prudence
sp.l: Be you he,
And go together quickly.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: You are, no tyrant?

sp.speaker: Prudence
sp.l: If I be madam, you were best appeal me!

sp.speaker: Lat.
sp.l: Beaufort —

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: I am busy, prithee let me alone:
I have a cause in hearing too.

sp.speaker: Lat.
sp.l: At what bar?

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Loves court o'requests!

sp.speaker: Lat.
sp.l: Bring't into the sovereignty:
It is the nobler court, afore judge Pru,
The only learned mother of the law!
And lady of conscience, too!

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: 'Tis well enough
Before this mistress of requests, where it is.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Let 'em not scorn you. Bear up master Lovel,
And take your hours, and kisses, they are a fortune.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: Which I cannot approve, and less make use of:

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Still i'this cloud! why cannot you make use of?

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: Who would be rich to be so soon undone?
The beggars best is wealth, he doth not know:
And, but to show it him, in flames his want:

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Two hours at height?

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: That joy is too too narrow,
Would bound a love, so infinite as mine:
And being passed, leaves an eternal loss.
Who so prodigiously affects a feast,
To forfeit health, and appetite, to see it?
Or but to taste a spoonful, would forgo
all gust of delicacy ever after?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: These, yet, are hours of hope.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: But all hours following
Years of despair, ages of misery!
Nor can so short a happiness, but spring
A world of fear, with thought of losing it;
Better be never happy, then to feel
A little of it, and then lose it ever.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: I do confess, it is a strict injunction;
But, than the hope is, it may not be kept.
A thousand things may intervene, we see
The wind shift often, thrice a day, sometimes;
Decrees may alter upon better motion,
And riper hearing. The best bow may start,
And th'hand may vary. Pru may be a sage
In law, and yet not sour, sweet Pru, smooth Pru,
Soft, debonair, and amiable Pru,
May do as well as rough, and rigid Pru;
And yet maintain her, venerable Pru,
Majestic Pru, and serenissimus Pru.
Try but one hour first, and as you like
The loose o'that, draw home and prove the other.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: If one hour could, the other happy make,
I should attempt it.

sp.speaker: Host
sp.l: Put it on: and do.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: Or in the blessed attempt that I might die!

sp.speaker: Host
sp.l: I marry, there were happiness indeed;
Transcendent to the melancholy, meant.
It were a fate, above a monument,
And all inscription, to die so. A death
For emperors to enjoy! And the Kings
of the rich East, to pawn their regions for;
To sow their treasure, open all their mines,
Spend all their spices to embalm their corpse,
And wrap the inches up in sheets of gold,
That fell by such a noble destiny!
And for the wrong to your friend, that fear's away,
He rather wrongs himself, following fresh light,
New eyes to swear by. If lord Beaufort change,
It is no crime in you to remain constant.
And upon these conditions, at a game
So urged upon you.

sp.speaker: Prudence
sp.l: Sir your resolution —

sp.speaker: Host
sp.l: How is the lady affected?

sp.speaker: Prudence
sp.l: Sou'raignes use not
To ask their subjects' suffrage where 'tis due;
But where conditional.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: A royal sovereign!

sp.speaker: Lat.
sp.l: And a rare states-woman. I admire her bearing
In her new regiment.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Come choose your hours,
Better be happy for a part of time,
Than not the whole: and a short part, then never.
Shall I appoint 'em, pronounce for you?

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: Your pleasure.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Then he designes his first hour after dinner;
His second after supper. Say ye? Content?

sp.speaker: Prudence
sp.l: Content.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: I am content.

sp.speaker: Lat.
sp.l: Content.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Content.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: What's that? I am content too.

sp.speaker: Lat.
sp.l: You have reason,
You had it on the by, and we observed it.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: Trot I am not content: in faith I am not.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Why art not thou content, good Sheleenien?

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: He tauk so desperate, and so debauched,
So bawdy like a courtier, and a lord,
God bless him, one that tak'th tobacco.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Very well mixed.
What did he say?

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: Nay, nothing to the purposh,
Or very little, nothing at all to purposh.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Let him alone nurse.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: I did tell him of Ser●
Was a great family come out of Ireland,
Descended of o Neale, Mac Con, Mac Dermot,
Mac Murrogh, but he marked not.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Nor do I,
Good Queen of heralds, ply the bottle, and sleep.

div.head: Scene 1.
div.stage: Tipto. Flie. Jug. Peirce. Jordan. Ferret. Trundle.
div.l: I like the plot of your militia, well!
It is a fine militia, and well ordered!
And the division's neat! 'twill be desired
Only, th'expressions were a little more Spanish:
For there's the best militia o'the world!
To call 'em tertias. Tertia of the kitchen,
The tertia of the cellar, tertia of the chamber,
And tertia of the stables.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: That I can, sir,
And find out very able, fit commanders.
In every Tertia.

sp.speaker: Tip.
sp.l: Now you are i'the right!
As i'the tertia o'the kitchen, yourself
Being a person, elegant in sauces,
There to command, as prime maestro deal Campo,
Chief master of the palate, for that tertia:
Or the cook under you, 'cause you are the marshal;
And the next officer i'the field, to the host.
Then for the cellar, you have young ano ne,
Is a rare fellow, what's his other name?

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: Pierce, sir.

sp.speaker: Tip.
sp.l: Sir pierce, I'll ha'him a cavalier.
Sir pierce anon, will pierce us a new hogshead!
And than your thoroughfare, Jug here, his Alferez:
An able officer, gi'me thy beard, round jug,
I take thee by this handle, and do love
One of thy inches! I'the chambers, Jordan, here.
He is the don, deal Campo o'the beds.
And for the stables, what's his name?

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: Old peck.

sp.speaker: Tip.
sp.l: Maestro deal Campo, peck! his name is curt,
A monosyllable, but commands the horse well.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: O, in an inn, sir, we have other horse,
Let those troops rest a while. Wine is the horse,
That we must charge with here.

sp.speaker: Tip.
sp.l: Bring up the troops,
Or call sweet fly, 'tis an exact militia,
And thou an exact professor, Lipsius fly,
Thou shalt be called, and jouse: lack ferret, welcome,
Old trenchmaster, and colonel o'the pioneers,
What canst thou bolt us now? A coney? or two
Out of Thom: trundles burrow, here, the coach?
This is the master of the carriages!
How is thy driving Thom: good, as 'twas?

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.l: It serves my lady, and our officer Pru.
Twelve mile an hour! ●hom has the old trundle still.

sp.speaker: Tip.
sp.l: I am taken with the family, here, fine fellows?
Viewing the muster roll.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.l: They are brave men!

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: And of the fly, blown discipline all, the quartermaster!

sp.speaker: Tip.
sp.l: The fly's a rare bird, in his profession!
Let's sip a private pint with him, I would have him
quit this light sign of the light heart, my bird:
And lighter house. It is not for his tall
And growing gravity so cedar-like,
To be the second to an host in cuerpo,
That knows no elegancies, use his own
Dictamen, and his genius, I would have him
Fly high, and strike at all. Here's young anon, too.

sp.speaker: Pei.
sp.l: What wine is't gentlemen, white or claret?

sp.speaker: Tip.
sp.l: White. My brisk anon.

sp.speaker: Pei.
sp.l: I'll draw you Juno's milk
That died the lilies, colonel.

sp.speaker: Tip.
sp.l: Do so pierce.

sp.speaker: Pec.
sp.l: A plague of all jades, what a clap he has gi'n me

sp.speaker: Fli.
sp.l: Why how now cousin?

sp.speaker: Tip.
sp.l: Who's that?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: The ostler.

sp.speaker: Fli.
sp.l: What ailest thou cousin peck?

sp.speaker: Pec.
sp.l: O me, my haunches!
As sure as you live, sir, he knew perfectly
