I meant to cozen him. He did leer so on me,
And then he sneered. As who would say take heed sirrah,
And when he saw our half-peck, which you know
Was but an old court-dish, lord how he stamped?
I thought, 't had been for joy. When suddenly
He cuts me a back caper with his heels,
And takes me just o'the crupper. Down come I
And my whole ounce of oats! Then he neighed out,
As if he had a mare by the tail.

sp.speaker: Fli.
sp.l: Troth cousin,
You are to blame to use the poor dumb Christians,
So cruelly, defraud 'em o'their dimensum,
Yonder's the colonel's horse (There I looked in)
Keeping our lady's Eve! The devil a bit
He has got, since he came in yet! There he stands,
and looks and looks, but 'tis your pleasure, coz,
He should look lean enough.

sp.speaker: Pec.
sp.l: He has hay before him.

sp.speaker: Fli.
sp.l: Yes, but as gross as hemp, and as soon will choke him,
Unless he eat it buttered. He'd four shoes,
And good ones, when he came in: it is a wonder,
With standing still he should cast three.

sp.speaker: Pec.
sp.l: Troth quartermaster,
This trade is a kind of mystery, that corrupts
Our standing manners quickly: once a week,
I meet with such a brush to mollify me.
Sometimes a brace, to awake my conscience,
Yet still, I sleep securely.

sp.speaker: Fli.
sp.l: Cousin peck,
You must use better dealing, faith you must.

sp.speaker: Pec.
sp.l: Troth, to give good example, to my successors,
I could be well content to steal but two girths,
And now and then a saddle cloth, change a bridle,
For exercise: and stay there.

sp.speaker: Fli.
sp.l: If you could
There were some hope, on you, coz. But the fate is
You are drunk so early, you mistake whole saddles:
Sometimes a horse.

sp.speaker: Pec.
sp.l: I there's —

sp.speaker: Fli.
sp.l: The wine, come coz, I'll talk with you anon.

sp.speaker: Pec.
sp.l: Do, lose no time, good quartermaster.

sp.speaker: Tip
sp.l: There are the horse, come, fly.

sp.speaker: Fli.
sp.l: Charge, in boys, in; lieutenant o'the ordinance.
Tobacco, and pipes.

sp.speaker: Tip.
sp.l: Who's that? Old Jordan, good!
A comely vessel, and a necessary.
New-scoured he is: here's to thee, martial fly.
In milk, my young anon says.

sp.speaker: Pei.
sp.l: Cream o'the grape!
That dropped from Juno's breasts, and sprung the lily!
I can recite your fables,

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: Here is, too,
The blood of Venus, mother o'the rose!

sp.speaker: Jor.
sp.l: The dinner is gone up.

sp.speaker: Jug.
sp.l: I hear the whistle.

sp.speaker: Jor.
sp.l: Ay, and the fiddlers. We must all go wait.

sp.speaker: Pei.
sp.l: Pox o'this waiting, quarter master, fly.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: When chambermaids are sovereigns, wait their Ladi●
Fly scorns to breath.

sp.speaker: Pec.
sp.l: Or blow upon them, he.

sp.speaker: Pei.
sp.l: Old parcel peck! Art thou there? how now? lame

sp.speaker: Pec.
sp.l: Yes faith: it is ill halting afore cripples,
I ha' got a dash of a jade, here, will stick by me.

sp.speaker: Pei.
sp.l: O you have had some fantasy, fellow peck,
Some revelation —

sp.speaker: Pec.
sp.l: What?

sp.speaker: Pei.
sp.l: To steal the hay,
Out o'the racks again:

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: I told him so,
When the guests backs were turned.

sp.speaker: Pei.
sp.l: Or bring 〈◊〉 pe●
The bottom onwards, heaped with oats; and cry.
Here's the best measure upon all the road! when
You know the guest, put in his hand, to feel,
And smell to the oats, that grated all his fingers
Upo'the wood —

sp.speaker: Pec.
sp.l: Mum!

sp.speaker: Pei.
sp.l: And found out your 〈◊〉

sp.speaker: Pec.
sp.l: I ha' been i'the cellar, pierce.

sp.speaker: Pei.
sp.l: You were th● there,
Upo'your knees; I do remember it:
To ha'the fact concealed. I could tell more,
Soaping of saddles, cutting of horse tails,
And cropping — pranks of ale, and hostelry —

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: Which he cannot forget, he says, young knight:
No more than you can other deeds of darkness,
Done i'the cellar.

sp.speaker: Tip.
sp.l: Well said, bold professor.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: We shall ha' some truth explained.

sp.speaker: Pei.
sp.l: We are all mortal,
And have our visions.

sp.speaker: Pec.
sp.l: Truly it seems to me
that every horse has his whole peck, and tumbles
Up to the ears in litter,

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: When, indeed
There's no such matter; not a smell of provender.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Not so much straw as would tie up a horse-tail!

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: Nor any thing i'the rack, but two old cob webs!
And so much rotten hay, as had been a hen's riest!

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.l: And yet he's ever apt to sweep the mangers!

sp.speaker: ●er
sp.l: But puts in nothing.

sp.speaker: Pei.
sp.l: These are fits, and fancies,
Which you must leave, good peck.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: And you must pray
It may be revealed to you, at sometimes,
Whose horse you ought to cozen; with what conscience;
The how; and when; a parson's horse may suffer —

sp.speaker: Pei.
sp.l: Who's master's double beneficed; put in that.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: A little greasing i'the teeth; 'tis wholesome:
And keeps him in a sober shuffle.

sp.speaker: Pei.
sp.l: His saddle too
May want a stirrup.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: And, it may be sworn,
His learning lay of one side, and so broke it.

sp.speaker: Pec.
sp.l: They have ever oats i'their cloak-bags, to affront us.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: And therefore 'tis an office meritorious,
To tith such soundly.

sp.speaker: Pei.
sp.l: And a grazier's may.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: O they are pinching puckfists!

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.l: And suspicious.

sp.speaker: Pei.
sp.l: Suffer before the master's face, sometimes.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: He shall think he sees his horse eat half a bushel,

sp.speaker: Pei.
sp.l: When the slight is, rubbing his gums with salt,
Till all the skin come off, he shall but mumble,
Like an old woman that were chewing brawn,
And drop 'em out again.

sp.speaker: Tip.
sp.l: Well argued cavalier,

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: It may do well: and go for an example:
But coz, have care of understanding horses,
Horses with angry heels, nobility horses.
Horses that know the world; let them have meat
Till their teeth ache; and rubbing till their ribs
Shine like a wench's forehead: they are devils else
Will look into your dealings.

sp.speaker: Pec.
sp.l: For mine own part,
The next I cousin o'the pampered breed,
I wish he may be foundered.

sp.speaker: Fli.
sp.l: Foundered.
Prolate it right.

sp.speaker: Pec.
sp.l: And of all four, I wish it,
I love no crupper compliments.

sp.speaker: Pei.
sp.l: Whose horse was it?

sp.speaker: Pec.
sp.l: Why, Mr. Bursts.

sp.speaker: Pei.
sp.l: Is Bat Burst come?

sp.speaker: Pec.
sp.l: An hour he has been here.

sp.speaker: Tip.
sp.l: What Burst?

sp.speaker: Pei.
sp.l: Mas, Bartolmew Burst.
One that hath been a citizen, since a courtier,
And now a gamester. Hath had all his whirls,
And bouts of fortune, as a man would say,
Once a bat, and ever a bat! A rearmouse,
And bird of twilight, he has broken thrice

sp.speaker: Tip.
sp.l: Your better man, the Genoway proverb say,
Men are not made of steel.

sp.speaker: Pei.
sp.l: Nor are they bounded
Always to hold.

sp.speaker: Fli.
sp.l: Thrice honourable colonel!
Hinges will crack -

sp.speaker: Tip.
sp.l: Though they be Spanish iron

sp.speaker: Pei.
sp.l: He is a merchant still, adventurer,
At in, and in: and is our thoroughfare's friend.

sp.speaker: Tip.
sp.l: Who? legs?

sp.speaker: Pei.
sp.l: The same: and a fine gentle
Was with him!

sp.speaker: Pec.
sp.l: Mr. Huffle.

sp.speaker: Pei.
sp.l: Who? Hodge H●

sp.speaker: Ti.
sp.l: What's he?

sp.speaker: Pei.
sp.l: A cheater, and another fine gentle
A friend of the chamberlains! Jordans! mr.Huffle
He is Bursts protection.

sp.speaker: Fli.
sp.l: Fights, and vapours for him

sp.speaker: Pei.
sp.l: He will be drunk so civilly -

sp.speaker: Fli.
sp.l: So discreetly -

sp.speaker: Pei.
sp.l: And punctually! just at his hour.

sp.speaker: Fli.
sp.l: And then
call for his Jordan, with that hum and state,
As if he pissed the politics!

sp.speaker: Pei.
sp.l: And sup
With his tuft-taffata night-gear, here, so silently!

sp.speaker: Fli.
sp.l: Nothing but music!

sp.speaker: Pei.
sp.l: A dozen of bawdy songs.

sp.speaker: Tip.
sp.l: And knows the general this?

sp.speaker: Fl.
sp.l: O no, sir dormis,
Dormit patronus, still, the master sleeps.
They'll steal to bed.

sp.speaker: Pei.
sp.l: In private sir, and pay,
The fiddlers with that modesty, next morning.

sp.speaker: Fli.
sp.l: Take a disiune of muscadel, and eggs!

sp.speaker: Pei.
sp.l: And pack away i' their trundling cheats, like Gipsies

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.l: Mysteries, mysteries, ferret.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: I we see, trundle,
What the great officers, in an inn may do;
I do not say the officers of the crown
But the light heart.

sp.speaker: Tip.
sp.l: I'll see the bat, and Huffle.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: I ha' some business sir, I crave your pardon -

sp.speaker: Tip.
sp.l: What?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: To be sober.

sp.speaker: Tip.
sp.l: Pox, go get you gone then.
Trundle shall stay.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.l: No I beseech you colonel,
Your lordship has a mind to be drunk private,
With these brave gallants; I will step aside
Into the stables, and salute my mares.

sp.speaker: Pei.
sp.l: Yes do: and sleep with 'em, let him go base— whipstock.
He's as drunk as a fish now, almost as dead.

sp.speaker: Tip.
sp.l: Come, I will see the flicker mouse, my fly.

div.head: Scene 2.
div.stage: Prudence ushered by the host, takes her seat of judicature, nurse, Frank, the two lords Beaufort, and Latimer, assist of the bench: the lady and Lovel are brought in, and sit on the two sides of the stage, confronting each the other.

sp.speaker: Prudence
sp.l: Here set the hour; but first produce the parties:
And clear the court. The time is now of price.

sp.speaker: Host
sp.l: Jug, get you down, and trundle get you up,
You shall be crier. Ferret here, the clerk.
Jordan, smell you without, till the ladies call you;
Take down the fiddlers too, silence that noise,
Deep, i'the cellar, safe.

sp.speaker: Prudence
sp.l: Who keeps the watch?

sp.speaker: Host
sp.l: Old sheelinin here, is the madam Tell-clock.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: No fait and trot, sweet master, I shall sleep;
I fait, I shall.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: I pray thee, do then, schrich. O●.
She brings to mind the fable o'the dragon,
That kept the Hesperian fruit. Would I could charm her.

sp.speaker: Host
sp.l: Trundle will do it with his hum. Come Trundle.
Precede him ferret, i'the form.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Oyez, oyez, oyez.
Whereas there hath been awarded,
By the Queen regent of love,
In this high court of sovereignty,
Two special hours of address,
To Herebert Lovel, appellant,
Against the lady Frampul, defendant
Herebert Lovel, come into the court.
Make challenge to thy first hour,
And save thee, and thy bail.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.l: O yez, etc.
Whereas, etc.
By the Qu. Etc.
●n this high, etc.
Two special, etc.
To Herebert, etc.
Against the, etc.
Herebert Lov. Etc.
Make, etc.
And ●ave, etc.

sp.speaker: Host
sp.l: Lo, louting where he comes into the court!
Clerk of the sovereignty take his appearance.
And how accoutred, how designed he comes!

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: 'Tis done. Now crier, call the lady Frampul,
And by the name of,
Francis, lady Frampul, defendant,
Come into the court,
Make answer to the award,
And save thee, and thy bail.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.l: Francis etc.
Come into the, etc.
Make answer, etc.
And save thee, etc.

sp.speaker: Host
sp.l: She makes a noble, and a just appearance.
Set it down likewise, and how armed she comes.

sp.speaker: Prudence
sp.l: Usher of love's court, give 'em their oath.
According to the form, upon love's missal.

sp.speaker: Host
sp.l: Arise, and lay your hands, upon the book.
sp.p:
Herebert Lovel appellant, and lady Frances Frampul, defendant, you shall swear upon the liturgy of love, Ovid de arte amandi, that you neither have, ne will have, nor in any wise bear about you, thing, or things, pointed, or blunt, within these these lists, other than
what are natural, and allowed by the court: no enchanted arms, or weapons, stones of virtue, herb of grace, charm, character, spell, philtre, or other power, then loves only, and the justness of your cause. So help you love, his mother, and the contents of this book: kiss it. Return unto your seats. Crier bid silence.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.l: Oyez. Oyez. Oyez.

sp.speaker: Fe.
sp.l: I'the name o'the sovereign of love
Notice is given by the court,
To the appellant, and defendant,
That the first hour of address proceeds.
And love save the sovereign.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.l: I'the etc.
Notice is etc.
To the ap etc.
That the etc.
And love etc.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.l: Every man, or woman keep silence pain of imprisonment.

sp.speaker: Prudence
sp.l: Do your endeavours, in the name of love.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: To make my first approaches, then, in love.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Tell us what love is, that we may be sure
There's such a thing, and that it is in nature.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: Excellent lady, I did not expect
To meet an infidel! much less an atheist!
Here in love's lists! of so much unbelief!
To raise a question of his being —

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Well-charged!

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: I rather thought, and, with religion, think,
Had all the character of love been lost,
His lines, dimensions, and whole signature
Razed, and defaced, with dull humanity:
That both his nature, and his essence might
Have found their mighty instauration here,
Here where the confluence of fair, and good,
Meets to make up all beauty. For, what else
is love, but the most noble, pure affection
Of what is truly beautiful, and fair?
Desire of union with the thing beloved?

sp.speaker: (Beau.
sp.l: Have the assistants of the court their votes,
And writ of privilege, to speak them freely?

sp.speaker: Prudence
sp.l: Yes, to assist; but not to interrupt.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Then I have read somewhere, that man and woman
Were, in the first creation, both one piece,
And being cleft asunder, ever since,
Love was an appetite to be rejoined.
As for example —

sp.speaker: N●r
sp.l: Cramo-cree! what meansh' tou?

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Only, to kiss, and part.

sp.speaker: Host
sp.l: So much is lawful.

sp.speaker: Lat.
sp.l: And stands with the prerogative of love's court!

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: It is a fable of Plato's, in his banquet,
And uttered, there, by Aristophanes.

sp.speaker: Host
sp.l: 'Twas well remembered here, and to good use.)
But on with your description, what love is.
Desire of union with the thing beloved.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: I meant a definition. For I make
The efficient cause, what's beautiful, and fair.
The formal cause, the appetite of union.
The final cause, the union itself.
But larger, if you'll have it, by description,
It is a flame, and ardour of the mind,
Dead, in the proper corpse, quick in another's:
Transfers the lover into the loved.
The he, or she, that loves, engraves, or stamps
Th' idea of what they love, first in themselves:
Or, like to glasses, so their minds take in
the forms of their beloved, and them reflect,
It is the likeness of affections,
Is both the parent, and the nurse of love.
Love is a spiritual coupling of two souls,
So much more excellent, as it least relates
Unto the body; circular, eternal;
N● feigned, or made, but born: and then, so precious,
As naught can value it, but itself. So free,
As nothing can command it, but itself.
And in itself, so round, and liberal,
As where it favours, it bestows itself.

sp.speaker: (Bea.
sp.l: And, that do I; here my whole self, I tender,
According to the practice o'the court.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: I'tish a naughty practish, a lewd practish,
Be quiet man, dou shalt not leap her, here.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Leap her? I lip her, foolish Queen at arms,
Thy blazon's false: wilt thou blaspheme thine office?)

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: But, we must take, and understand this love
Along still, as a name of dignity;
Not pleasure.

sp.speaker: (Host
sp.l: Mark you that, my light young lord?)

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: True love hath no unworthy thought, no light,
Loose, unbecoming appetite, or strain,
But fixed, constant, pure, immutable.

sp.speaker: (Bea.
sp.l: I relish not these philosophical feasts:
Give me a banquet o'sense, like that of Ovid:
A form, to take the eye; a voice, mine care;
Pure aromatiques, to my scent; a soft,
Smooth, dainty hand, to touch; and, for my taste,
Ambrosiac kisses, to melt down the palate.)

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: They are the earthly, lower form of lovers,
are only taken with what strikes the senses!
And love by that loose scale. Although I grant,
We like, what's fair and graceful in an object,
And (True) would use it, in the all we tend to,
Both of our civil, and domestic deeds.
In ordering of an army, in our style,
Apparel, gesture, building, or what not?
All arts, and actions do affect their beauty.
But put the case, in travail I may meet
Some gorgeous structure, a brave frontispiece,
Shall I stay captive o'th' outer court,
Surprised with that, and not advance to know
Who dwells there, and inhabiteth the house?
There is my friendship to be made, within;
With what can love me again: not, with the walls,
Doors, windows, architrabes, the frieze, and coronice.
My end is lost in loving of a face,
An eye, lip, nose, hand, foot, or other part,
Whose all is but a statue, if the mind
Move not, which only can make the return.
The end of love is, to have two made one
In will, and in affection, that the minds
Be first inoculated, not the bodies.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Give me the body, if it be a good one.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Nay, sweet my lord, I must appeal the sovereign
For better quarter; if you hold your practice;
True. Silence, pain of imprisonment: hear the court.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: The body's love is frail, subject to change,
And alter still, with it: the minds is firm,
One, and the same, proceedeth first, from weighing,
and well examining, what is fair, and good;
Then, what is like in reason, fit in manners;
That breeds good will: good will desire of union.
So knowledge first, begets benevolence,
Benevolence breeds friendship, friendship love.
And where it starts or steps aside from this,
It is a mere degenerous appetite,
A lost, oblique, depraved affection,
And bears no mark, or character of love.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: How am I changed! By what alchemy
Of love, or language, am I thus translated!
His tongue is tipped with the philosopher's stone,
And that hath touched me through every vain!
I feel that transmutation o'my blood,
As I were quite become another creature,
And all he speaks, it is projection!

sp.speaker: Prudence
sp.l: Well feigned, my lady: now her parts begin!

sp.speaker: Lat.
sp.l: And she will act 'em subtly.

sp.speaker: Prudence
sp.l: She fails me else.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: Nor do they trespass within bounds of pardon,
That giving way, and licence to their love,
Divest him of his noblest ornaments,
Which are his modesty, and shamefacedness:
And so they do, that have unfit designs,
Upon the parties, they pretend to love.
For, what's more monstrous, more a prodigy,
Then to hear me protest truth of affection
Unto a person that I would dishonour?
And what's a more dishonour, then defacing
Another's good, with forfeiting mine own?
And drawing on a fellowship of sin;
from note of which, though (For a while) we may
Be both kept safe, by caution, yet the conscience
Cannot be cleansed. For what was hitherto
Called by the name of love, becomes destroyed
Then, with the fact: the innocency lost,
The bating of affection soon will follow:
And love is never true, that is not lasting.
No more than any can be pure, or perfect,
That entertains more than one object. Dixi.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: O speak, and speak for ever! let min'eare
Be feasted still, and filled with this banquet!
No sense can ever surfeit on such truth!
It is the marrow of all lovers tenants!
Who hath read Plato, Heliodore, or Tatius,
Sidney, D'urse, or all love's fathers, like him?
He, is there the master of the sentences,
Their school, their commentary, text, and gloss,
And breathes the true divinity of love!

sp.speaker: Prudence
sp.l: Excellent actor! how she hits this passion!

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Where have I lived, in heresy, so long
Out o'the congregation of love,
And stood irregular, by all his canons?

sp.speaker: L●.
sp.l: But do you think she plays?

sp.speaker: Prudence
sp.l: Upo' my sovereignty,
Mark her anon.

sp.speaker: Lat.
sp.l: I shake, and am half jealous.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: What penance shall I do, to be received,
And reconciled, to the church of love?
Go on procession, barefoot, to his image,
And say some hundred penitential verses,
There, out of Chaucer's Troilus, and Cressid?
Or to his mother's shrine, vow a wax-candle
as large as the town maypole is, and pay it!
Enjoin me any thing this court thinks fit,
For I have trespassed, and blasphemed love.
I have, indeed, despised his deity,
Whom (Till this miracle wrought on me) I knew not.
Now I adore love, and would kiss the rushes
That bear this reverend gentleman, his priest,
If that would expiate — but, I fear it will not.
For, though he be somewhat struck in years, and old
Enough to be my father, he is wise,
And only wise men love, the other covet.
I could begin to be in love with him,
But will not tell him yet, because I hope
T'enjoy the other hour, with more delight,
And prove him farther.

sp.speaker: Prudence
sp.l: Most Socratic lady!
Or, if you will ironic! give you joy
Of you Platonic love here, mr.Lovel.
But pay him his first kiss, yet, i'the court,
Which is a debt, and due: for the hour's run.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: How swift is time, and s●ly steals away
From them would hug it, value it, embrace it?
I should have thought it scarce had run ten minutes,
When the whole hour is fled. Here, take your kiss, sir,
Which I most willing tender you, in court.

sp.speaker: (Bea.
sp.l: And we do imitate —)

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: And I could wish,
It had been twenty — so the sovereign's
Poor narrow nature had decreed it so —
But that is past, irrevocable, now:
She did her kind, according to her latitude —

sp.speaker: Prudence
sp.l: Beware, you do not conjure up a spirit
you cannot lay.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: I dare you, do your worst,
Show me but such an injustice: I would thank you
To alter your award.

sp.speaker: Lat.
sp.l: Sure she is serious!
I shall have another fit of jealousy!
I feel a grudging!

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Cheer up, noble guest,
We cannot guess what this may come to, yet;
The brain of man, or woman, is uncertain!

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: T●t, she dissembles! All is personated,
And counterfeit comes from her! If it were not,
The Spanish monarchy, with both the Indies,
Could not buy off the treasure of this kiss,
Or half give balance for my happiness.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Why, as it is yet, it glads my light heart
To see you roused thus from a sleepy humour,
Of drowsy, accidental melancholy;
And all those brave parts of your soul awake,
That did before seem drowned, and buried in you!
That you express yourself, as you had backed
The muse's horse! or got Bellerophon's arms!
What news with fly?

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: News, of a newer lady,
A finer, fresher, braver, bonnier beauty,
A very bonaroba, and a bouncer!
In yellow, glistering, golden satin.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Pru,
Adjourn the court.

sp.speaker: Prudence
sp.l: Cry Trundle -

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.l: Oyez,
Any man, or woman, that hath any personal attendance
To give unto the court; keep the second hour,
And love save the sovereign.

div.head: Scene 1.
div.l: O Barnabe!

sp.speaker: Jor.
sp.l: Welcome Barnabe! Where hast thou been?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: I'the foul weather.

sp.speaker: Jug.
sp.l: Which has wet thee, B●.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: As dry as a chip! Good jug, a cast o'thy name,
As well as thy office; two jugs!

sp.speaker: Jug.
sp.l: By, and by.

sp.speaker: Jor.
sp.l: What lady's this thou hast brought here?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: A great lady
I know no more: one, that will try you, Jordan.
She'll find your gage, your circle, your capacity,
How does old Staggers the smith? and tree, the saddler?
Keep they their Penny-club, still?

sp.speaker: Jor.
sp.l: And th'old catch too,
Of whoop Barnaby -

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Do they sing at me?

sp.speaker: Jor.
sp.l: They're reeling at it, in the parlour, now:

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: I'll to 'em: give me a drink first.

sp.speaker: Jor.
sp.l: Wher● thy hat

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: I lost it by the way gi'me— another.

sp.speaker: Jug.
sp.l: A hat?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: A drink.

sp.speaker: Jug.
sp.l: Take heed of taking cold, Ban -

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: The wind blew't off at Highgate, and my lady
Would not endure me, light, to take it up,
But made me drive bareheaded i'the rain.

sp.speaker: Jor.
sp.l: That she might be mistaken for a countess?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Troth, like enough! She might be an o'ergrown Duchess,
For ought I know.

sp.speaker: Jug.
sp.l: What! with one man!

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: At a time,
They carry no more, the best of'hem.

sp.speaker: I●
sp.l: Nor the bravest.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: And she is very brave!

sp.speaker: I●r.
sp.l: A stately gown!
And petticoat, she has on!

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Ha'you spied that, Jordan
You're a notable peerer, an old rabbi,
At a smock's hem, boy.

sp.speaker: Jug.
sp.l: As he is chamberlain,
He may do that, by his place.

sp.speaker: Jor.
sp.l: What's her squire?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: A toy, that she allows eight pence a day.
A slight man-net, to port her, up, and down.
Come show me to my playfellows, old Staggers,
And father tree.

sp.speaker: Jor.
sp.l: Here, this way, Barnabe.

div.head: Scene 2.
div.l: Come, let us take in fresco, here, one quart.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: Two quarts, my man of war, let us not be stinted.

sp.speaker: Huf.
sp.l: Advance three jordans, varlet o'the house:

sp.speaker: Tip.
sp.l: I do not like your Burst, bird; he is saucy:
Some shopkeeper he was?

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: Yes, sir.

sp.speaker: Tip.
sp.l: I knew it.
A broke-winged shopkeeper? I nose 'em, straight.
He had no father, I warrant him, that durst own him;
Some foundling in a stall, or the church porch;
Brought up i'the hospital; and so bound prentice;
Then master of a shop; than one o'th inquest;
Then breaks out bankrupt; or starts alderman:
The original of both is a church-porch —

sp.speaker: Fli.
sp.l: Of some, my colonel.

sp.speaker: Tip.
sp.l: Good faith, of most!
O'your shop citizens, they're rude animals!
And let 'em get but ten mile out a town
Th'out swagger all the wapentake.

sp.speaker: Fli.
sp.l: What's that?

sp.speaker: Tip.
sp.l: A Saxon word, to signify the hundred.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: Come let us drink, sir glorious, some brave health
Upon our tiptoes.

sp.speaker: Tip.
sp.l: To the health o'the bursts.

sp.speaker: Bu.
sp.l: Why Bursts?

sp.speaker: Ti.
sp.l: Why tipto's?

sp.speaker: Bu.
sp.l: On I cry you mercy!

sp.speaker: Tip.
sp.l: It is sufficient.

sp.speaker: Huf.
sp.l: What is so sufficient?

sp.speaker: Tip.
sp.l: To drink to you is sufficient.

sp.speaker: Huf.
sp.l: On what terms?

sp.speaker: Tip.
sp.l: That you shall give security to pledge me.

sp.speaker: Huf.
sp.l: So you will name no Spaniard, I will pledge you.

sp.speaker: Tip.
sp.l: I rather choose to thirst: and will thirst ever,
Then leave that cream of nations, uncried up.
Perish all wine, and gust of wine.

sp.speaker: Huf.
sp.l: How spill it?
Spill it at me?

sp.speaker: Tip.
sp.l: I wrek not, but I spilt it.

sp.speaker: Fli.
sp.l: Nay pray you be quiet, noble bloods.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: No Spaniards,
I cry, with my cousin Huffle.

sp.speaker: Huf.
sp.l: Spaniards? Pilchers?

sp.speaker: Tip.
sp.l: Do not provoke my patient blade. It sleeps,
And would not hear thee: Huffle, thou art rude,
And dost not know the Spanish composition.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: What is the recipe? Name the ingredients.

sp.speaker: Tip.
sp.l: Valour.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: Two ounces!

sp.speaker: Tip.
sp.l: Prudence.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: Half a dram!

sp.speaker: Tip.
sp.l: Justice,

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: A penny weight!

sp.speaker: Tip.
sp.l: Religion.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: Three scruples!

sp.speaker: Tip.
sp.l: And of gravida'd

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: A face-full!

sp.speaker: Tip.
sp.l: He carries such a dose of it in his looks,
Actions, and gestures, as it breeds respect,
To him, from savages, and reputation
With all the sons of men.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: Will it give him credit
With gamesters, courtiers, citizens, or tradesmen?

sp.speaker: Tip.
sp.l: He'll borrow money on the stroke of his beard!
Or turn off his mustachio! His mere cuello,
Or ruff about his neck is a bill of exchange
in any bank, in Europe! Not a merchant
That fees his gate, but straight will furnish him
Upon his pa●e!

sp.speaker: Huf.
sp.l: I have heard the Spanish name
Is terrible, to children in some countries;
And used to make them eat — their bread and butter:
Or take their wormseed.

sp.speaker: Tip.
sp.l: Huffle, you do shuffle:
— to them: stuff, Pinnacia.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: Slid here's a lady!

sp.speaker: Huf.
sp.l: And a lady gay!

sp.speaker: Tip.
sp.l: A well-trimmed lady!

sp.speaker: Huf.
sp.l: Let's lay her a board.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: Let's hail her first.

sp.speaker: Tip.
sp.l: By your sweet favour lady,

sp.speaker: Stu.
sp.l: Good gentlemen be civil, we are strangers.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: And you were Flemings, sir!

sp.speaker: Huf.
sp.l: Or Spaniards!

sp.speaker: Tip.
sp.l: They're here, have been at Seville i'their days,
And at Madrid too!

sp.speaker: Pin.
sp.l: He is a foolish fellow,
I pray you mind him not, he is my protection.

sp.speaker: Tip.
sp.l: In your protection, he is safe, sweet lady.
So shall you be, in mine.

sp.speaker: Huf.
sp.l: A share, good colonel.

sp.speaker: Tip.
sp.l: Of what?

sp.speaker: Huf.
sp.l: Of your fine lady! I am Hodge,
My name is Huffle.

sp.speaker: Tip.
sp.l: Huffling Hodge, be quiet.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: And I pray you, be you so, glorious colonel,
Hodge Huffle shall be quiet.

sp.speaker: Huf.
sp.l: A lady gay, gay.
For she is a lady gay, gay, gay. For she's a lady gay.

sp.speaker: Tip.
sp.l: Bird o'the Vespers, vespertilio, Burst;
You are a gentleman, of the first head,
But that head may be broke, as all the body is —
Burst, if you tie not up your Huffle, quickly.

sp.speaker: Huf.
sp.l: Tie dogs, not man.

sp.speaker: Hur.
sp.l: Nay pray thee, Hodge, be still.

sp.speaker: Tip.
sp.l: This steel here rides not, on this thigh, in vain.

sp.speaker: Huf.
sp.l: Show'st thou thy steel, and thigh, thou glorious dirt,
than Hodge sings Sampson, and no ties shall hold.
— Peirce. Jug. Iorden.

sp.speaker: Pei.
sp.l: Keep the peace gentlemen: what do you m●

sp.speaker: Tip.
sp.l: I will not discompose myself, for Huffle.

sp.speaker: Pin.
sp.l: You see what your entreaty, and pressure still
Of gentlemen, to be civil, doth bring on?
A quarrel? and perhaps manslaughter? You
Will carry your goose about you, still? your pla●ing 〈◊〉
Your tongue to smooth all is not here fine stuff?

sp.speaker: Stu.
sp.l: Why wife?

sp.speaker: Pin.
sp.l: Your wife? ha' not I forbidden you that▪
Do you think I'll call you husband i'this gown,
Or any thing, in that jacket, but protection?
Here tie my shoe; and show my vellute petticoat,
And my silk stocking! why do you make me a lady,
If I may not do like a lady, in fine clothes.

sp.speaker: Stu.
sp.l: Sweet heart, you may do what you will, with me.

sp.speaker: Pin.
sp.l: 〈◊〉; I knew that at home; what to do with you;
But why was I brought hither? to see fashions?

sp.speaker: Stu.
sp.l: And wear them too, sweet heart, but this wild company

sp.speaker: Pin.
sp.l: Why do you bring me in wild company?
You'd ha' me tame, and civil, in wild company?
I hope I know, wild company are fine company,
And in fine company, where I am fine myself,
A lady may do any thing, deny nothing
To a fine party, I have heard you say't.
— to them pierce.

sp.speaker: Pei.
sp.l: There are a company of ladies above
Desire your ladyship's company, and to take
The surety of their lodgings, from the affront
of these half-beasts, were here e'en now, the centaurs,

sp.speaker: Pin.
sp.l: Are they fine ladies?

sp.speaker: Pei.
sp.l: Some very fine ladies.

sp.speaker: Pin.
sp.l: As fine as I?

sp.speaker: Pei.
sp.l: I dare use no comparisons,
Being a servant, sent —

sp.speaker: Pin.
sp.l: Spoken, like a fine fellow!
I would thou wert one; I'd not then deny thee:
But, thank thy lady.
— to them host.

sp.speaker: Host
sp.l: Madam, I must crave you
To afford a lady a visit, would excuse
Some harshness o'the house, you have received
From the brute guests.

sp.speaker: Pin.
sp.l: This's a fine old man!
I'd go with him an' he were a little finer!
Stu● you may sweet heart, it is mine host.

sp.speaker: Pin.
sp.l: Mine host!

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Yes madam, I must bid you welcome.

sp.speaker: Pin.
sp.l: Do then.

sp.speaker: Stu.
sp.l: But do not stay.

sp.speaker: Pin.
sp.l: I'll be advised by you, yes!

div.head: Scene. 3.
div.stage: — To them Latimer. Beaufort. Lady. Pru. Frank. Host. Pinnacia. Stuffe.
div.l: What more than Thracian barbarism was this!

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: The battle o'the centaurs, with the Lapithes!

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: There is no taming o'the monster drink.

sp.speaker: Lat.
sp.l: But what a glorious beast our Tipto showed!
He would not discompose himself, the don!
Your Spaniard, near, doth discompose himself.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Yet, how he talked, and roared i'the beginning!

sp.speaker: Prudence
sp.l: And ran as fast, as 'a knocked marrowbone.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: So they did all at last, when Lovel went down,
And chased hem bout the court.

sp.speaker: Lat.
sp.l: For all's don Lewis!
Or fencing after Euclid!

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: I ne'er saw
A lightning shoot so, as my servant did,
His rapier was a meteor, and he waved it
Over 'em, like a comet! as they fled him!
I marked his manhood! every stoop he made
Was like an eagles, at a flight of cranes!
(As I have read somewhere.)

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Bravely expressed:

sp.speaker: Lat.
sp.l: And like a lover!

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Of his valour, I am!
He seemed a body, rarified, to air!
Or that his sword, and arm were of a piece,
They went together so! Here, comes the lady.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: A bouncing bonaroba! as the fly said.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: She is some giantess! I'll stand off,
For fear she swallow me.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Is not this our gown, Pru?
That I bespoke of Stuffe?

sp.speaker: Prudence
sp.l: It is the fashion!

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Ay, and the silk! Feel, sure it is the same!

sp.speaker: Prudence
sp.l: And the same petticoat, lace, and all!

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: I'll swear it.
How came it hither? make a bill of inquiry.

sp.speaker: Prudence
sp.l: You've a fine suit on, madam! and a rich one!

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: And of a curious making!

sp.speaker: Prudence
sp.l: And a new!

sp.speaker: Pin.
sp.l: As new, as day.

sp.speaker: Lat.
sp.l: She answers like a fishwife.

sp.speaker: Pin.
sp.l: I put it on, since noon, I do assure you,

sp.speaker: Prudence
sp.l: Who is your tailor?

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Pray you, your fashioners name.

sp.speaker: Pin
sp.l: My fashioner is a certain man of mine own,
He is i'the house: no matter for his name.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: O, but to satisfy this bevy of ladies:
Of which a brace, here, longed to bid you welcome

sp.speaker: Pin.
sp.l: He's one, in truth, I title my protection:
Bid him come up.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Our new lady's protection!
What is your ladyship's style?

sp.speaker: Pin.
sp.l: Countess Pinnaccia.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Countess Pinnacia's man, come to your lady,

sp.speaker: Prudence
sp.l: Your ladyship's tailor! mass, stuff!

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: How Stuffe?
He the protection!

sp.speaker: Host
sp.l: Stuff looks like a remnant.

sp.speaker: Stu.
sp.l: I am undone, discovered!

sp.speaker: Prudence
sp.l: 'Tis the suit, madam,
Now, without scruple! and this, some device
To bring it home with.

sp.speaker: Pin.
sp.l: Why, upon your knees?
Is this your lady godmother?

sp.speaker: Stu.
sp.l: M●m, Pinnacia.
It is the lady Frampul: my best customer.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: What show is this, that you present us with?

sp.speaker: Stu.
sp.l: I do beseech your ladyship, forgive me.
She did but say the suit on.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Who? Which she?

sp.speaker: Stu.
sp.l: My wife forsooth.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: How? Mistress Stuffe? Your wife!
Is that the riddle?

sp.speaker: Prudence
sp.l: We all looked for a lady,
A Duchess, or a countess at the least.

sp.speaker: Stu.
sp.l: She is my own lawfully begotten wife,
In wedlock. We ha' been coupled now seven years.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: And why thus masked? You like a footman, ha!
And she your countess!

sp.speaker: Pin.
sp.l: To make a fool of himself
And of me too.

sp.speaker: Stu.
sp.l: I pray thee, pinnace, peace.

sp.speaker: Pin.
sp.l: Nay it shall out, since you have called me wife,
And openly dis-ladied me! though I am dis-countessed
I am not yet discountenanced. These shall see.

sp.speaker: Host
sp.l: Silence!

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.l: It is a foolish trick madam, he has;
For though he be your tailor, he is my beast.
I may be bold with him, and tell his story.
When he makes any fine garment will fit me,
Or any rich thing that he thinks of price,
Then must I put it on, and be his countess,
Before he carry it home unto the owners.
A coach is hired, and four horse, he runs
In his velvet jacket thus, to Rumford, Croyden,
Hounslow, or Barnet, the next bawdy road:
And takes me out, carries me up, and throws me
Upon a bed.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Peace thou immodest woman:
She glories in the bravery o'the vice.

sp.speaker: Lat.
sp.l: 'Tis a quaint one!

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: A fine species,
Of fornicating with a man's own wife,
Found out by (What's his name?)

sp.speaker: Lat.
sp.l: Mr. Nic Stuffe!

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: The very figure of preoccupation
In all his customers best clothes.

sp.speaker: Lat.
sp.l: He lies
With his own succuba, in all your names.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: And all your credits.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Ay, and at all their costs.

sp.speaker: Lat.
sp.l: This gown was then bespoken, for the sovereign

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: I marry was it.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: And a main offence,
Committed 'gainst the sovereignty: being not brought
Home i'the time. Beside, the profanation,
Which may call on the censure of the court.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Let him be blanketed. Call up the quartermaster.
Deliver him o'er, to fly.

sp.speaker: Stu.
sp.l: O good my lord.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Pillage the pinnace.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Let his wife be stripped.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Blow off her upper deck.

sp.speaker: Lat.
sp.l: Tear all her tackle,

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Pluck the polluted robes over her ears;
Or cut them all to pieces, make a fire o'them:

sp.speaker: Prudence
sp.l: To rags, and cinders, burn th'idolatrous vestures.

sp.speaker: Host
sp.l: Fly, and your fellows, see that the whole censure
Be thoroughly executed.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: We'll toss him, bravely.
Till the stuff stink again.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: And send her home,
Divested to her flannel, in a cart.

sp.speaker: Lat.
sp.l: And let her footman beat the basin afore her.

sp.speaker: Fli.
sp.l: The court shall be obeyed.

sp.speaker: Host
sp.l: Fly, and his officers
Will do it fiercely.

sp.speaker: Stu.
sp.l: Merciful Queen Pru.

sp.speaker: Prudence
sp.l: I cannot help you.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Go thy ways Nic Stuffe,
Thou hast nicked it for a fashioner of venery!

sp.speaker: Lat.
sp.l: For his own hell! though he run ten mile for't.

sp.speaker: Prudence
sp.l: O here comes Lovel, for his second hour.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: And after him, the type of Spanish valour.

div.head: Scene 4.
div.stage: Lady. Lovel. Tipto. Latimer. Beaufort. Pru. Frank. Nurse. Host.
div.l: Servant, what have you there?

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: A meditation,
Or rather a vision, madam, and of beauty
Our former subject.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Pray you let us hear it.

lg.l: It was a beauty that I saw
So pure, so perfect, as the frame
Of all the universe was lame,
To that one figure, could I draw,
Or give least line of it a law!
A skein of silk without a knot!
A fair march made without a halt!
A curious form without a fault!
A printed book without a blot.
All beauty, and without a spot.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: They are gentle words, and would deserve a note,
Set to 'em, as gentle.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: I have tried my skill.
To close the second hour, if you will hear them,
My boy by that time will have got it perfect.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Yes, gentle servant. In what calm he speaks,
After this noise, and tumult, so unmoved,
With that serenity of countenance,
As i● his thoughts did acquiesce in that
Which is the object of the second hour,
And nothing else.

sp.speaker: Prudence
sp.l: Well then summon the court.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: I have a suit to the sovereign of love,
If it may stand with the honour of the court,
To change the question but from love, to valour,
To hear, it said, but, what true valour is,
Which oft begets true love.

sp.speaker: Lat.
sp.l: It is a question
Fit for the court, to take true knowledge of,
And hath my just assent.

sp.speaker: Prudence
sp.l: Content.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Content.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Content. I am content, give him his oath.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Herebert Lovel, thou shalt swear upon the testament of love, to make answer to this question propounded to thee by the court, what true valour is. And therein to tell the truth, the whole truth, and nothing but the truth. So help thee love, and thy bright sword at need.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: So help me love and my good sword at need.
It is the greatest virtue, and the safety
Of all mankind, the object of it is danger.
A certain mean 'twixt fear, and confidence:
no inconsiderate rashness, or vain appetite
Of false encountering formidable things;
But a true science of distinguishing
What's good or evil. It springs out of reason,
And tends to perfect honesty, the scope
Is always honour, and the public good:
It is no valour for a private cause.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: No? not for reputation?

sp.speaker: Lov
sp.l: That's man's idol,
Set up 'gainst God, the maker of all laws,
Who hath commanded us we should not kill;
And yet we say, we must for reputation.
What honest man can either fear his own,
Or else will hurt another's reputation?
Fear to do base, unworthy things, is valour,
If they be done to us, to suffer them,
Is valour too. The office of a man
That's truly valiant, is considerable
Three ways: the first is in respect of matter,
Which still is danger; in respect of form,
Wherein he must preserve his dignity;
And in the end, which must be ever lawful.

sp.speaker: Lat.
sp.l: But men, when they are heated, and in passion,
Cannot consider.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: Then it is not valour.
I never thought an angry person valiant:
Virtue is never aided by a vice.
What need is there of anger, and of tumult?
When reason can do the same things, or more?

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: O yes, 'tis profitable, and of use,
It makes us fierce, and fit to undertake.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: Why so will drink make us both bold, and rash.
Or frenzy if you will, do these make valiant?
They are poor helps, and virtue needs them not.
No man is valianter by being angry,
But he that could not valiant be without:
So, that it comes not in the aid of virtue,
But in the stead of it.

sp.speaker: Lat.
sp.l: He holds the right.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: And 'tis an odious kind of remedy,
To owe our health to a disease.

sp.speaker: Tip.
sp.l: If man
Should follow the dictamen of his passion,
He could not scape —

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: To discompose himself.

sp.speaker: Lat.
sp.l: According to don Lewis!

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Or Caranza!

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: Good colonel glorious, whilst we treat of valour,
Dismiss yourself.

sp.speaker: Lat.
sp.l: You are not concerned.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: Go drink,
And congregate the ostlers, and the tapsters,
The under-officers of your regiment;
Compose with them, and be not angry valiant!

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: How does that differ from true valour?

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: Thus.
In the efficient, or that which makes it,
For it proceeds from passion, not from judgement:
Then brute beasts have it, wicked persons, there
It differs in the subject: in the form,
'Tis carried rashly, and with violence:
Then i'the end, where it respects not truth,
Or public honesty; but mere revenge.
Now confident, and undertaking valour,
Sways from the true, two other ways; as being
A trust in our own faculties, skill, or strength,
And not the right, or conscience o'th' cause,
that works it: then i'the end, which is the victory,
And not the honour.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: But the ignorant valour
That knows not why it undertakes, but doth it
T'escape the infamy merely —

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: Is worst of all:
That valour lies, i'the eyes o'the lookers on;
And is called valour with a witness.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Right:

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: The things true valour is exercised about,
Are poverty, restraint, captivity,
Banishment, loss of children, long disease:
The least is death. Here valour is beheld,
Properly seen; about these it is present:
Not trivial things, which but require our confidence.
And, yet to those, we must object ourselves,
Only for honesty: if any other
Respect be mixed, we quite put out her light.
And as all knowledge, when it is removed
Or separate from justice, is called craft,
Rather than wisdom: so a mind affecting,
Or undertaking dangers, for ambition,
Or any self pretext, not for the public,
Deserves the name of daring, not of valour,
And over-daring is as great a vice,
As over-fearing.

sp.speaker: Lat.
sp.l: Yes, and often greater.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: But as is not the mere punishment,
But cause that, makes a martyr, so it is not
Fighting, or dying; but the manner of it
Renders a man himself. A valiant man
Ought not to undergo, or tempt a danger,
But worthily, and by selected ways:
He undertakes with reason, not by chance.
His valour is the salt to his other virtues,
They are all unseasoned without it. The waiting maids,
Or the concomitants of it, are his patience,
His magnanimity, his confidence,
His constancy, security, and quiet;
He can assure himself against all rumour!
Despairs of nothing! laughs at contumelies!
As knowing himself, advanced in a height
Where injury cannot reach him, nor aspersion
Touch him with soil!

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Most manly uttered all!
As if Achilles had the chair in valour,
And Hercules were but a lecturer!
Who would not hang upon those lips for ever!
That strike such music? I could run on them;
But modesty is such a school mistress,
To keep our sex in awe.

sp.speaker: Prudence
sp.l: Or you can feign! my
Subtle and dissembling lady mistress.

sp.speaker: Lat.
sp.l: I fear she means it, Pru, in too good earnest!

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: The purpose of an injury 'tis to vex
And trouble me: now, nothing can do that,
To him that's valiant. He that is affected
With the least injury, is less than it.
It is but reasonable, to conclude
That should be stronger, still, which hurts, then that
Which is hurt. Now no wickedness is stronger,
Then what opposeth it: not fortune's self,
When she encounters virtue, but comes off
Both lame, and less! why should a wise man then,
Confess himself the weaker, by the feeling
Of a fool's wrong? There may an injury
be meant me, I may choose, if I will take it.
But we are, now, come to that delicacy,
And tenderness of sense, we think an insolence
Worse than an injury, bear words worse than deeds;
We are not so much troubled with the wrong,
As with the opinion of the wrong! like children,
We are made afraid with visors! Such poor sounds
As is the lie, or common words of spite.
Wise laws thought never worthy a revenge;
And 'tis the narrowness of humane nature,
Our poverty, and beggary of spirit,
To take exception at these things. He laughed at me!
He broke a jest! A third took place of me!
How most ridiculous quarrels are all these?
Notes of a queasy, and sick stomach, labouring
With want of a true injury! the main part
Of the wrong, is, our vice of taking it.

sp.speaker: Lat.
sp.l: Or our interpreting it to be such.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: You take it rightly. If a woman, or child
Give me the lie, would I be angry? no,
Not if I were i'my wits, sure I should think it
No spice of a disgrace. No more is theirs,
If I will think it, who are to be held
In as contemptible a rank, or worse.
I am kept out a masque, sometime thrust out,
Made wait a day, two, three, for a great word,
Which (When it comes forth) is all frown, and forehead!
What laughter should this breed, rather than anger!
Out of the tumult, of so many errors,
To feel, with contemplation, mine own quiet?
If a great person do me an affront,
A giant of the time, sure, I will bear it
Or out of patience, or necessity!
Shall I do more for fear, then for my judgement?
For me now to be angry with Hodge Huffle,
Or Burst (His broken charge) if he be saucy,
Or our own type of Spanish valour, Tipto,
(Who were he now necessited to beg
Would ask an alms, like conde Olivares)
Were just to make myself, such a vain animal
As one of them. If light wrongs touch me not,
No more shall great; if not a few, not many.
There's naught so sacred with us but may find
A sacrilegious person, yet the thing is
No less divine, cause the profane can reach it.
He is shot free, in battle, is not hurt,
Not he that is not hit. So he is valiant,
That yields not unto wrongs; not he that scapes 'em
They that do pull down churches, and deface
The holiest altars, cannot hurt the godhead.
A calm wise man may show as much true valour,
Amidst these popular provocations,
As can an able captain show security,
By his brave conduct, through an enemy's country.
A wise man never goes the people's way,
But as the planets still move contrary
To the world's motion; so doth he, to opinion:
He will examine, if those accidents
(Which common fame calls injuries) happen to him
Deservedly, or no? come they deservedly,
they are no wrongs then, but his punishments:
If undeservedly, and he not guilty,
The doer of them, first, should blush, not he.

sp.speaker: Lat.
sp.l: Excellent!

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Truth, and right!

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: An oracle
Could not have spoken more!

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Been more believed!

sp.speaker: Prudence
sp.l: The whole court runs into your sentence, sir!
And see, your second hour is almost ended.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: It cannot be! O clip the wings of time,
Good Pru, or make him stand still with a charm.
Distil the gout into it, cramps, all diseases
T'arrest him in the foot, and fix him here:
Oh, for an engine, to keepe back all clocks!
Or make the sun forget his motion!
If I but knew what drink the time now loved,
To set my trundle at him, mine own Barnabe!

sp.speaker: Prudence
sp.l: Why? I'll consult our shelee nine, to-mas.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: Er grae chreest.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Wake her not.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: Tower een cuppan
D'vsque bagh done.

sp.speaker: Prudence
sp.l: Usquebagh's her drink.
But 'twillnot make the time drunk.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: As't hath her,
Away with her, my lord, but marry her first. Pru,

sp.speaker: Prudence
sp.l: Ay, that will be sport anon too, for my lady.
But she hath other game to fly at yet:
The hour is come, your kiss.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: My servant's song, first.

sp.speaker: Prudence
sp.l: I say the kiss, first; and I so enjoined it:
At your own peril, do, make the contempt.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Well sir, you must be paid, and legally.

sp.speaker: Prudence
sp.l: Nay nothing, sir, beyond.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: One more I— except.
This was but half a kiss, and I would change it.

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.l: The court's dissolved, removed, and the play ended.
No sound, or air of love more, I decree it.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: From what a happiness hath that one word
Thrown me, into the gulf of misery?
To what a bottomless despair? how like
A court removing, or an ended play
Shows, my abrupt precipitate estate,
By how much more my vain hopes were increased
By these false hours of conversation?
Did not I prophesy this, of myself,
And gave the true prognostics? O my brain!
How art thou turned! and my blood congealed!
My sinews slackened! and my marrow melted!
That I remember not where I have been,
Or what I am? Only my tongue's on fire;
And burning downward, hurls forth coals, and cinders,
To tell, this temple of love, will soon be ashes!
Come indignation, now, and be my mistress,
No more of love's ingrateful tyranny.
His wheel of torture, and his pits of birdlime,
His nets of nooses, whirlpools of vexation,
His mills, to grind his servants into powder —
I will go catch the wind first in a sieve,
Weigh smoke, and measure shadows, plough the wa●,
And sow my hopes there, ere I stay in love.

sp.speaker: La●.
sp.l: My jealousy is off, I am now secure.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: Farewell the craft of crocodiles, women's piety,
And practice of it, in this art of flattering,
And fooling men. I ha' not lost my reason,
Though I have lent myself out, for two hours,
Thus to be baffled by a chambermaid,
and the good actor, her lady, afore mine host,
Of the light heart, here, that hath laughed at all — 〈◊〉,

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Who I?

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: Laugh on, sir, I'll to bed, and sleep,
And dream away the vapour of love, if th'house
And your leer drunkards let me. Lad. Pru.

sp.speaker: Prudence
sp.l: Sweet madam.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Why would you let him go thus?

sp.speaker: Prudence
sp.l: In whose power
Was it to stay him, properer than my ladies!

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Why, in her ladies? Are not you the sovereign?

sp.speaker: Prudence
sp.l: Would you, in conscience, madam, ha me vex
His patience more?

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Not but apply the cure,
Now it is vexed.

sp.speaker: Prudence
sp.l: That's but one bodies work.
Two cannot do the same thing handsomely.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: But had not you the authority, absolute?

sp.speaker: Prudence
sp.l: And were not you i'rebellion, lady Frampul,
From the beginning?

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: I was somewhat froward,
I must confess, but frowardness sometime
Becomes a beauty, being but a visor
Put on. You'll let a lady wear her mask, Pru.

sp.speaker: Prudence
sp.l: But how do I know, when her ladyship is pleased
To leave it off, except she tell me so?

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: You might ha' known that by my looks, and language,
Had you been or regardant, or observant.
One woman, reads another's character,
Without the tedious trouble of deciphering:
If she but give her mind to't, you knew well,
It could not sort with any reputation
Of mine, to come in ●st, having stood out
So long, without conditions, for mine honour.

sp.speaker: Prudence
sp.l: I thought you did expect none, you so jeered him,
and put him off with scorn -

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.l: Who, I, with scorn?
I did express my love, to idolatry rather,
And so am justly plagued, not understood.

sp.speaker: Prudence
sp.l: I swear, I thought you had dissembled, madam,
And doubt, you do so yet.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Dull, stupid, wench!
Stay i'thy state of ignorance still, be damned,
An idiot chambermaid! Hath all my care,
My breeding thee in fashion, thy rich clothes,
Honours, and titles wrought no brighter effects
On thy dark soul, then thus? Well! go thy ways,
Were not the tailor's wife, to be demolished,
Ruined, uncased, thou shouldst be she, I vow.

sp.speaker: Prudence
sp.l: Why, take your spangled properties, your gown,
And scarves.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Pru, Pru, what dost thou mean?

sp.speaker: Prudence
sp.l: I will not buy this playboy's bravery,
At such a price, to be upbraided for it,
Thus, every minute.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Take it not to heart so.

sp.speaker: Prudence
sp.l: The tailor's wife? There was a word of sco●

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.l: It was a word fell from me, Pru, by chance.

sp.speaker: Prudence
sp.l: Good madam, please to undeceive yourself,
I know when words do slip, and when they are darted
With all their bitterness: uncased? demolished?
An idiot — chambermaid, stupid, and dull?
Be damned for ignorance? I will be so.
And think I do deserve it, that, and more,
Much more I do.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Here comes mine host! No crying!
Good Pru. Where is my servant Lovel, host?

sp.speaker: Host
sp.l: You ha' sent him up to bed, would, you would follow him!
And make my house amends!

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Would you advise it?

sp.speaker: Host
sp.l: I would I could command it. My light heart
should leap till midnight.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Pray thee be not sullen,
I yet must ha' thy counsel. Thou shalt wear, Pru,
The new gown, yet.

sp.speaker: Prudence
sp.l: After the tailor's wise?

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Come, be not angry, or grieved: I have a project.

sp.speaker: Host
sp.l: Wake Sheleenien Thomas! Is this your heraldry?
And keeping of records, to lose the main?
Where is your charge?

sp.speaker: N●r.
sp.l: Gra ●hreest!

sp.speaker: Host
sp.l: Go ask, th'oracle
O'the bottle, at your girdle, there you lost it:
You are a sober setter of the watch.

div.head: Scene 1.
div.l: Come fly, and legacy, the bird o'the heart:
Prime insect of the ●nne, professor, quartermaster,
As ever thou deserved'st thy daily drink,
Paddling in sack, and licking i'the same,
Now show thyself an implement of price,
And help to raise a nap to us, out of nothing,
Thou sawst 'em married?

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: I do think, I did,
And heard the words, Philip, I take thee, Latice,
I gave her too, was then the father fly,
And heard the priest do his part, far as five nobles
Would lead him i'the lines of matrimony.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Where were they married?

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: ●'th ne● stable,

sp.speaker: (Host
sp.l: Ominous!
I ha' known many a church been made a stable,
But not a stable made a church till now
I wish 'em joy. Fly, was he a full priest?

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: He bellied for it, had his velvet sleeves,
And his branched cassock, a side sweeping gown,
All his formalities , a good crammed divine!
I went not far to fetch him, the next inn,
Where he was lodged, for the action.

sp.speaker: Host
sp.l: Had they a licence?

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: Licence of love, I saw no other, and purse,
To pay the duties both of church, and house,
The angels flew about.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Those birds send luck:
And mirth will follow. I had thought to ha' sacrificed,
To merriment tonight , i'my light heart, fly,
And like a noble poet, to have had
My last act best: but all fails i'the plot.
Lovel is gone to bed; the lady Frampul
And sovereign Pru fallen out: Tipto, and his regiment
Of mine-men, all drunk dumb, from his whop Barnaby,
To his hoop Trundle: they are his two Tropicks.
No project to rear laughter on, but this,
The marriage of lord Beaufort, with Laetitia.
Stay! what's here! The satin gown redeemed!
And Pru restored in't, to her lady's grace!

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: She is set forth in't! rigged for some employment!

sp.speaker: Host
sp.l: An embassy at least!

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: Some treaty of state!

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: 'Tis a fine tack about! and worth the observing.

div.head: Scene 2.
div.l: Sweet Pru, ay, now thou art a Queen indeed!
These robes do royally! and thou becomest 'em!
So they do thee! rich garments only fit
The parties they are made for! they shame others.
How did they show on goody tailors back!
Like a caparison for a sow, God save us!
Thy putting hem on hath purged, and hallowed 'em
From all pollution, meant by the mechanics.

sp.speaker: Prudence
sp.l: Hang him poor snip, a secular shop-wit!
He hath naught but his shears to claim by, and his measures,
His prentice may as well put in, for his needle,
And plead a stitch.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: They have no taint in 'em,
Now o'the tailor.

sp.speaker: Prudence
sp.l: Yes, of his wife's haunches,
Thus thick of fat; I smell 'em, o'the say.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: It is restorative, Pru! with thy but chafing it,
A barren hind's grease may work miracles.
Find but his chamber door, and he will rise
To thee! or if thou pleasest, fain to be
The wretched party herself , and comest unto him
In forma pauperis, to crave the aid
Of his knight errant valour, to the rescue
Of thy distressed robes! name but thy gown,
And he will rise to that! Pru. I'll fire the charm first,
I had rather die in a ditch, with mistress shore,
Without a smock, as the pitiful matter has it,
Then owe my wit to clothes, or ha' it beholden.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Still spirit of Pru!

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: And smelling o'the sovereign!

sp.speaker: Prudence
sp.l: No, I will tell him, as it is, indeed;
I come from the fine, froward, frampold lady,
One was run mad with pride, wild with self-love,
But late encountering a wise man, who scorned her,
And knew the way to his own bed, without
Borrowing her warming pan, she hath recovered
Par● of her wits: so much as to consider
How far she hath trespassed, upon whom, and how.
And now sits penitent and solitary,
Like the forsaken turtle, in the volary
Of the light heart, the cage, she hath abused,
Mourning her folly, weeping at the height
She measures with her eye, from whence she is fallen,
Since she did branch it, on the top o'the wood.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: I pray thee Pru, abuse me enough, that's use me
As thou thinkest fit, any course way, to humble me,
Or bring me home again, or Lovel on:
Thou dost not know my sufferings, what I feel,
My fires, and fears, are met: I burn, and freeze,
My liver's one great coal, my heart shrunk up
With all the fevers, and the mass of blood
Within me, is a standing lake of fire,
Curled with the cold wind of my gelid sighs,
That d●ine a drift of sleet through all my body,
And shoot a February through my veins.
Until I see him, I am drunk with thirst,
and surfeited with hunger of his presence.
I know not where I am, or no, or speak,
Or whether thou dost hear me.

sp.speaker: Prudence
sp.l: Spare expressions.
I'll once more venture for your ladyship,
So you will use your fortunes reverent.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Religiously, dear Pru, love and his mother,
I'll build them several churches, shrines, and altars,
And over head, I'll have, in the glass windows,
The story of this day be painted, round,
For the poor laity of love to read,
I'll make myself their book, nay their example,
To bid them take occasion by the forelock,
And play no after-games of love, hereafter.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: And here your host, and's fly, witness your vows.
And like two lucky birds, bring the presage
Of a loud jest: lord Beaufort married is.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Ha!

sp.speaker: Fli.
sp.l: All to be married.

sp.speaker: Prudence
sp.l: To whom, not your son?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: The same

sp.speaker: Prudence
sp.l: If her ladyship could take truce
A little with her passion, and give way
To their mirth now running.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Runn's it mirth, let't come,
It shall be well received, and much made of it.

sp.speaker: Prudence
sp.l: We must of this, it was our own conception.

div.head: Scene 3.
div.l: Room for green rushes, raise the fiddlers, chamberlain,
Call up the house in arms.

sp.speaker: Host
sp.l: This will rouse Lovel.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: And bring him on too.

sp.speaker: Lat.
sp.l: Shelee-neen.
Runs like a heifer, bitten with the breeze,
About the court, crying on fly, and cursing.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: For what, my lord?

sp.speaker: Lat.
sp.l: You were best hear that from her,
It is no office, fly, fits my relation.
Here come the happy couple! Joy, lord Beaufort.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: And my young lady too.

sp.speaker: Host
sp.l: Much joy, my lord!

div.head: Scene 4.
div.l: I thank you all, I thank thee, father fly.
Madam, my cousin, you look discomposed,
I have been bold with a salad, after supper,
On your own lettuce, here:

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: You have, my lord.
But laws of hospitality, and fair rites,
Would have made me acquainted.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: I' your own house,
I do acknowledge: else, I much had trespassed.
But in an inn, and public, where there is licence
Of all community: a pardon of course
May be sued out.

sp.speaker: Lat.
sp.l: It will, my lord, and carry it.
I do not see, how any storm, or tempest
Can help it, now.

sp.speaker: Prudence
sp.l: The thing being done, and past,
You bear it wisely, and like a lady of judgement.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: She is that, secretary Pru.

sp.speaker: Prudence
sp.l: Why secretary?
My wise lord? is your brain lately married?

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Your reign is ended, Pru, no sovereign now:
Your date is out, and dignity expired.

sp.speaker: Prudence
sp.l: I am annulled, how can I treat with Lovel,
Without a new commission?

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Thy gown's commission.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Have patience, Pru, expect, bid the lord joy.

sp.speaker: Prudence
sp.l: And this brave lady too. I wish them joy.

sp.speaker: Pei.
sp.l: Joy. Jour. Joy. Jug. All joy.

sp.speaker: Host
sp.l: Ay, the house full of joy.

sp.speaker: Fly
sp.l: Play the bells, fiddlers, crack your strings with joy.

sp.speaker: Prudence
sp.l: But lady Letice, you showed a neglect
Un-to-be-pardoned, towards my lady, your kinswoman,
Not to advise with her.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Good politic Pru,
Urge not your state-advice, your afterwit;
'Tis near upbraiding. Get our bed ready, chamberlain,
And host, a bride-cup, you have rare conceits,
And good ingredients, ever an old host
Upo'the road, has his provocative drinks.

sp.speaker: Lat.
sp.l: He is either a good bawd, or a physician.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: 'Twas well he heard you not, his back was turned.
A bed, the genial bed, a brace of boys
Tonight I play for.

sp.speaker: Prudence
sp.l: Give us points, my lord.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Here take 'em, Pru, my codpiece point, and all,
I ha' clasps, my Letice a●mes here take 'em boys.
What is the chamber ready? speak, why stare you!
On one another?

sp.speaker: Jor.
sp.l: No sir.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: And why no?

sp.speaker: Jor.
sp.l: My master has forbid it. He yet doubts
That you are married.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Ask his vicar general,
His fly, here.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: I must make that good, they are married.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: But I must make it bad, my hot young lord.
Give him his doublet again, the air is piercing;
You may take cold, my lord. See whom you ha' married,
Your host's son, and a boy.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: You are abused.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Much joy, my lord.

sp.speaker: Prudence
sp.l: If this be your Latitia,
she'll prove a counterfeit mirth, and a clipped lady.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: A boy, a boy; my lord has married a boy.

sp.speaker: Lat.
sp.l: Raise all the house in shout, and laughter, a boy!

sp.speaker: H●st
sp.l: Stay, what is here! peace rascals, stop your throats.

div.head: Scene 5.
div.l: That maggot, worm, that insect! O my child,
My daughter! where's that fly? I'll fly in his face,
The vermin, let me come to him.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: Why nurse Shele●?

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: Hang thee thou parasite, thou son of crumbs,
And orts, thou hast undone me, and my child,
My daughter, my dear daughter.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: What means this?

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: O sir, my daughter, my dear child is ruined,
By this your fly, here, married in a stable,
And sold unto a husband.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Stint thy cry,
Harlot, if that be all, didst thou not sell him
To me for a boy? and broughtest him in boys rags,
Here to my door, to beg an alms of me?

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: I did good Mr., and I crave your pardon.
But 'tis my daughter, and a girl.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Why saidst thou
It was a boy, and sold'st him then, to me
With such entreaty, for ten shillings, Carlin?

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: Because you were a charitable man
I heard, good Mr., and would breed him well,
I would ha' given him you, for nothing, gladly.
Forgive the lie of my mouth, it was to save
The fruit of my womb. A parents needs are urgent.
And few do know that tyrant o'er good natures.
But you relieved her, and me too, the mother,
And took me into your house to be the nurse,
For which heaven heap all blessings on your head,
Whilst there can one be added.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Sure thou speakst
Quite like another creature, than thou'st lived,
Here, i'the house, a shelee-neen Thomas,
An Irish beggar.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: So I am, God help me.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: What art thou? tell, the match is a good match,
For ought I see: ring the bells once a gain.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Stint, I say, fiddlers.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: No going off my lord.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Nor coming on sweet lady, things thus standing!

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: But what's the heinousness of my offence?
Or the degrees of wrong you suffered by it?
In having your daughter matched thus happily,
Into a noble house, a brave young blood,
And a prime peer o'the realm?

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Was that your plot, fly?
Give me a cloak, take her again among you.
I'll none of your light-heart fosterlings, no inmates,
Suppositions fruits of an host's bra●ne,
And his flies hatching, to be put upon me.
There is a royal court o'the star-chamber
Will scatter all these mists, disperse these vapours,
And clear the truth. Let beggars match with beggars.
That shall decide it, I will try it there.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: Nay then my lord, it's not enough, I see
You are licentious, but you will be wicked.
Ye are not alone content to take my daughter,
Against the law; but having taken her,
You would repudiate, and cast her off,
Now, at your pleasure, like a beast of power,
Without all cause, or colour of a cause,
That, or a noble, or an honest man,
Should dare t'except against, her poverty.
Is poverty a vice?

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Th'age counts it so.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: God help your lordship, and your peers that think so,
If any be: if not, God bless them all,
And help the number o'the virtuous,
If poverty be a crime. You may object
Our beggary to us, as an accident,
But never deeper, no inherent baseness.
And I must tell you, now, young lord of dirt,
As an incensed mother, she hath more,
And better blood, running i'those small veins,
Than all the race of Beaufort's have in mass,
Though they distil their drops from the left rib
Of John of Gaunt.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Old mother of records,
Thou knowest her pedigree, then: whose daughter is she?

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: The daughter and coheir to the lord Frampul,
This lady's sister!

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Mine? what is her name?

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: Laetitia.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: That was lost?

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: The true Latitia.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Sister, oh gladness! Then you are our mother?

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: I am, dear daughter.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: On my knees, I bless
The light I see you by.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: And to the author
Of that blessed light, I open my other eye,
Which hath almost, now, seven year been shut,
Dark, as my vow was, never to see light,
till such a light restored it, as my children,
Or your dear father, who (I hear) is not.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Give me my wife, I own her now, and will have her.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: But you must ask my leave first, my young lord,
Leave is but light. Ferret, go bolt your master,
Here's gear will startle him. I cannot keep
The passion in me, I am ●ne turned child,
And I must weep. Fly, take away mine host,
My beard, and cap here, from me, and fetch my lord.
I am her father, sir, and you shall now
Ask my consent, before you have her. Wife!
My dear and loving wife! my honoured wife!
Who here hath gained but I? I am lord Frampul,
The cause of all this trouble? I am he
Have measured all the shires of England over:
Wales, and her mountains, seen those wilder nations,
Of people in the Peake, and Lancashire;
Their pipers, fiddlers, rushers, puppet-masters,
Jugglers, and Gipseys, all the sorts of canters,
And colonies of beggars, tumblers, ape-carriers,
For to these savages I was addicted,
To search their natures, and make odd discoveries!
And here my wife, like a she Mandevile,
Ventured in disquisition, after me.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: I may look up, admire, I cannot speak
Yet, to my lord.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Take heart, and breath, recover,
Thou hast recovered me, who here had coffined
Myself alive, in a poor hostelry,
In penance of my wrongs done unto thee
Whom I long since gave lost.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: So did I you,
till stealing mine own daughter from her sister,
I lighted on this error hath cured all.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: And in that cure, include my trespass, mother,
And father, for my wife -

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: No, the star-chamber.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Away with that, you sour the sweetest lettuce
Was ever tasted.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Gi'you joy, my son,
Cast her not off again. O call me father,
Lovel, and this your mother, if you like:
But take your mistress, first, my child; I have power
To give her now, with her consent, her sister
Is given already to your brother Beaufort.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: Is this a dream now, after my first sleep?
Or are these fantasies made i'the light heart?
And sold i'the new inn?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Best go to bed,
And dream it over all. Let's all go sleep,
Each with his turtle. Fly, provide us lodgings,
Get beds prepared: ye are master now o'the inn,
The lord o'the light heart, I give it you.
Fly, was my fellow Gipsy. All my family,
Indeed, were Gipseys, tapsters, ostlers, chamberlains,
Reduced vessels of civility.
But here stands Pru, neglected, best deserving
Of all that are i'the house, or i'my heart,
Whom though I cannot help to a fit husband,
I'll help to that will bring one, a just portion:
I have two thousand pound in bank, for Pru,
Call for it when she will

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: And I as much.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: There's somewhat yet, four thousand pound! that's better,
Then sounds the proverb, four bare legs in a bed.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: Me, and her mistress, she hath power to coin
Up, into what she will.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Indefinite Pru.

sp.speaker: Lat.
sp.l: But I must do the crowning act of bounty!

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: What's that, my lord?

sp.speaker: Lat.
sp.l: Give her myself,
By all the holy vows of love I do,
Spare all your promised portions, she is a dowry which here
So all sufficient in her virtue and manners,
That fortune cannot add to her.

sp.speaker: Prudence
sp.l: My lord,
Your praises, are instructions to mine ears,
Whence, you have made your wife, to live your servant.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Lights, get us several lights.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: Stay let my Mrs
But hear my vision sung, my dream of beauty,
Which I have brought, prepared, to bid us joy,
And light us all to bed, 'twill be instead
Of airing of the sheets with a sweet odour.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: 'Twill be an incense to our sacrifice
Of love tonight , where I will woo afresh,
And like Maecenas, having but one wife,
I'll marry her, every hour of life, hereafter.

div.stage: They go out, with a song.

lg.l: Plays in themselves have neither hopes, nor fears,
Their fate is only in their hearers ears:
If you expect more than you had tonight ,
The maker is sick, and sad. But do him right,
He meant to please you: for he sent things fit,
In all the numbers, both of sense, and wit,
If they ha' not miscarried! if they have,
All that his faint, and faltering tongue doth crave,
Is, that you not impute it to his brain.
That's yet unhurt, although set round with pain,
It cannot long hold out. All strength must yield.
Yet judgement would the last be, i the field,
With a true poet. He could have haled in
The drunkards, and the noises of the inn,
In his last act; if he had thought it fit
To vent you vapours, in the place of wit:
But better 'twas, that they should sleep, or spew,
Then in the scene to offend or him, or you.
This he did think; and this do you forgive:
When ere the carcase dies, this art will live.
And had he lived the care of King, and Queen,
His art in something more yet had been seen;
But majors, and sheriffs may yearly fill the stage:
A King's, or poet's birth do ask an age.

div.head: Another epilogue there was, made for the play in the poet's defence, but the play lived not, in opinion, to have it spoken.

lg.l: A jovial host, and lord of the new inn,
Cleped the light heart, with all that passed therein,
Hath been the subject of our play tonight ,
To give the King, and Queen, and court delight.
But, than we mean, the court above the stairs,
And passed the guard; men that have more of ears,
Than eyes to judge us: such as will not hiss
Because the chambermaid was named Cis.
We think, it would have served our scene as true,
If, as it is, at first we had called her Pru,
For any mystery we there have found,
Or magic in the letters, or the sound.
She only meant was, for a girl of wit,
To whom her lady did a province fit:
Which she would have discharged, and, done as well,
Had she been christened Joyce, grace, Doll, or Nell.

div.head: The just indignation the author took at the vulgar censure of his play, by some malicious spectators, begat this following ode to himself.

lg.l: Come leave the loathed stage,
And the more loathsome age:
Where pride, and impudence (In faction knit)
Usurp the chair of wit!
Indicting, and arraigning every day
Something they call a play.
Let their fastidious, vain
Commission of the brain
Run on, and rage, sweat, censure, and condemn:
They were not made for thee, less, thou for them.
Say, that thou pourest them wheat,
And they will acorns eat:
'Twere simple fury, still, thyself to waste
On such as have no taste!
To offer them a surfeit of pure bread,
Whose appetites are dead!
No, give them grains their fill,
Husks, draff to drink, and swill.
If they love lees, and leave the lusty wine,
Envy them not their palates, with the swine.
No doubt some mouldy tale,
Like Pericles; and stale
As the shrieves custs, and nasty as his fishscraps, out every dish,
Thrown forth, and raked into the common tub,
May keep up the play-club:
There, sweepings do as well
As the best ordered meal.
For, who the relish of these guests will fit,
Needs set them, but, the almsbasket of wit.
And much good do't you then:
Brave plush, and velvet-men;
Can feed on orts: and safe in your stage-clothes,
Dare quit, upon your oaths,
The stagers, and the stage-wrights too (Your peers)
Of larding your large ears
With their foul comic socks;
Wrought upon twenty blocks:
Which, if they are torn, and turned, and patched enough,
The gamesters share your guilt, and you their stuff.
Leave things so prostitute,
And take the Alcaic lute;
Or thine own Horace, or Anacreon's lyre;
Warm thee, by Pindar's fire:
And though thy nerves be shrunk, and blood be cold,
Ere years have made thee old;
Strike that disdainful heat
Throughout, to their defeat:
As curious fools, and envious of thy strain,
May, blushing, swear no palsey's in thy brain.
But, when they hear thee sing
The glories of thy King,
His zeal to God, and his just awe o'er men;
They may, blood shaken, then,
Feel such a flesh-quake to possess their powers:
As they shall cry, like ours
In sound of peace, or wars,
No harp ere hit the stars;
In tuning forth the acts of his sweet reign:
And raising Charles his chariot, 'bove his wain.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
